metadata.title: X.509 Certificate Policy for the U.S. Federal PKI Common Policy Framework

revisions.remarks: Revised Common Policy (RFC 3647 format)
2007-01: Alignment of Cryptographic Algorithm Requirements with SP 800-78-1
2007-02: Requiring the inclusion of a subject DN in PIV Authentication Certificates
2007-03: Accommodating legacy PKIs for PIV Authentication
2008-01: § 8.3 Assessor’s Relationship to Assessed Entity
2008-02: Include a provision for a role-based signature certificate
2009-01:  nextUpdate in Certificate Revocation Lists (CRL) published by legacy Federal PKIs
2009-02: Allow the use of the PIV Authentication certificate as proof of identity and employment
2010-01: Align key length requirements w/ SP 800-57  2010-02: Remote Administration of Certification Authorities
2010-03: Allowing inclusion of UUIDs in Card Authentication Certificates
2010-05: Clarify the archive definition and how its records are intended to be used
2010-06: Allow Federal Legacy PKIs to Directly Cross Certify with Common Policy CA
2010-07: Legacy use of SHA-1 during transition period Jan 1, 2011 to Dec 31, 2013
2010-08: Clarify requirement to support CA Key Rollover
2011-01: CAs to assert policy OIDs in OCSP responder certificates for which the OCSP responder is authoritative
2011-02: Clarify requirements for device Subscribers and certificates
2011-03: Remove Requirements for LDAP References in Certificates

2012-01: Clarify RA audit requirements: revise Section 1.3.1.5, add new last sentence to first paragraph of Section 8, revise first paragraph of Section 8.1, revise Sections 8.4, 8.5, and 8.6, revise "Policy Management Authority (PMA)" glossary definition.

2012-02: Add new Section 4.1.1.4, Code Signing Certificates, to address change proposal (approved by FPKIPA on 6/12/12) requiring organizations receiving a code signing certificate to have access to a Time Stamp Authority.

2012-03: Add new language to Sections 3.2.3.2 and 9.6.3 to address change proposal (approved by FPKIPA on 8/14/12) to allow a human device sponsor, who is not physically located near the sponsored device, and/or who does not have sufficient administrative privileges on the sponsored device to fulfill these responsibilities, to delegate them to an authorized administrator of the device. 2012-04: Revise Section 4.9.7 to address change proposal (approved by FPKIPA on 8/12/12) to detail and clarify the Common Policy CA’s CRL issuance policies to ensure Offline Root CA operations are permitted.

2012-05: Revise Sections 1.2, 1.4.1, 3.1.1, 6.2.8, 6.3.2, 7.1.4, 7.1.6, and add new Sections 6.1.1.4 and 6.2.4.6 to address change proposal (approved by FPKIPA on 12/6/12) to create a new Common PIV Content Signing Policy OID.

2013-01: Clarify places in the Common Policy CP which were flagged during the FPKIMA Annual Audit as either contradictory with the FBCA CP or contradictory to current best practices.Clarify division of responsibilities between Trusted Roles (Section 5.2.1); clarify meaning of “all Security Audit logs (Section 5.4.1), and allow audit logs to be removed from production site once reviewed (Section 5.4.3) 2013-02: Remove SHA-1 policies from Common Policy.
2013-03: Require PIV Cards to be on the GSA Approved Products List (APL) Prior to Issuance and require annual PIV card testing.
2015-01: Create two new Common Derived PIV Authentication Certificate Policy OIDs in the Common Policy, and change/add text in appropriate sections throughout the CP.

2016-01: Alignment with CAB Forum Baseline Requirements (BR) v1.3.4.This will facilitate FPKI conformance to CAB Forum BRs for publicly-trusted SSL/TLS certificates, which will help promote inclusion of the Federal Root in public trust stores and provide guidance for issuance of publicly-trusted device certificates. 2016-02: Allow a long term CRL when a CA retires a key after performing a key changeover to align with the FPKI CPS.
2016-03: Remove or update references to obsoleted RFCs.Changes to Sections 1.3.1.7, 3.1.2, 3.1.4, 4.9.7, and 10.

2017-01: Align CP with current FPKIMA practice for CA certificates. 2017-02: Require CAs to publish information pertaining to resolved incidents on their websites. 2017-03: Require CAs to notify the FPKIPA whenever a change is made to their infrastructure 2017-04: Clarifies the period of time PIV card stock can continue to be used once it has been removed from the GSA APL.
2018-01: Key Recovery for key management certificates issued under the COMMON Policy

2018-02: Add reference to Annual Review Requirements 2018-03: Mandate specific EKUs in certificates issued after June 30, 2019 2018-04: Certificate revocation requirements for Transitive Closure after August 15, 2018 2018-05: Requirements for virtual implementations
2018-06: Incorporate “supervised remote identity proofing” and other new guidance as defined in NIST SP 800-63-3 effective as of October 4, 2018

2018-07: Remove the common-public-trusted-serverAuth certificate policy and associated requirements effective as of February 8, 2019 2018-08: Permit retention of private signing key(s) following CA termination effective as of February 8, 2019
2020-01: Add support for federally issued Personal Identity Verification-Interoperable (PIV-I) credentials
2020-02: Consolidated update to Common Policy and associated profiles, effective as of September 1, 2021.See the change proposal cover sheet for more detail.
2021-01: Consolidated Key Recovery Policy requirements into Common Policy.

2020-02: Updates to Section 5.4 and Section 5.5 to clarify the purpose of audit and archive, align recorded events and clarify archive retention periods. Updated reference links included.Implementation date is November 1, 2022. 2020-03: Removes the prohibition on container technology and generalizes terminology. Effective as of December 1, 2021.

2022-01A: Update to Section 5.5.2 to provide specificity for archive record retention periods, assisting RAs, or other archiving elements, to understand what artifacts need to be archived, and for how long in certain scenarios. Implementation date is November 1, 2022.

2023-02: Incorporates changes to multiple sections based on the comments received by the CPWG to include certificate suspension requirements, 3rd party key recovery request handling, public key parameters, key generation specifics, and remote workstation definition. Changes effective as of September 1, 2023.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This certificate policy (CP) includes the following distinct certificate policies:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Three Personal Identity Verification (PIV) authentication policies;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A PIV Interoperable (PIV-I) authentication policy for use by federal agencies;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A PIV Card Authentication policy;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A PIV-I Card Authentication policy for use by federal agencies;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A policy for devices that sign PIV data objects;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A policy for federal devices that sign PIV-I data objects;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A policy for Human Subscribers with software cryptographic modules;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A policy for Human Subscribers with hardware cryptographic modules;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A high assurance policy for Human Subscribers;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A policy for devices with software cryptographic modules; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A policy for devices with hardware cryptographic modules.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In this document, the term “device” means a non-person entity, i.e., a hardware device or software application.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates intended for code signing are not covered by this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where a specific policy is not stated, the requirements in this specification apply equally to all policies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Human Subscriber policies apply to certificates issued to federal employees, contractors, and other affiliated personnel for the purposes of authentication, signature, and confidentiality.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP was explicitly designed to support access to federal systems that have not been designated national security systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Certification Authority (CA) that operates in accordance with this CP will provide the following security management services:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Key generation/storage

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Key escrow and recovery

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificate generation, modification, re-key, and distribution

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificate revocation list (CRL) generation and distribution

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Repository management of certificate related items

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificate token initialization/programming/management

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - System management functions (e.g., security audit, configuration management, archive.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Key Recovery System (KRS) is required for CAs operating under this policy that issue PIV key management certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRS provides the computer system hardware, software, staff and procedures to store private keys securely and recover them when appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any CA that asserts these policies in certificates must obtain prior approval from the Federal PKI Policy Authority; approval is dependent upon a Certification Practices Statement (CPS) that clearly describes how each requirement in this CP is fulfilled, or, for Federal agencies that operate their own PKI, a comparable CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For any section of this policy containing no stipulation, the CPS must indicate whether it is applicable, and if so, describe the associated practices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operated by federal agencies that issue certificates under this policy may operate simultaneously under other policies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that operate simultaneously under this policy and under other policies must assert at least one policy in all issued certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs must not assert the OIDs in this policy in certificates unless they are issued in accordance with all the requirements of this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The root Certification Authority (CA) associated with the Common Policy Framework is the Federal Common Policy CA, operated by the Federal PKI Management Authority (FPKIMA).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP follows the RFC 3647 framework.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP applies only to CAs owned by or operated on behalf of the Federal Government that issue certificates according to this policy.

groups.title: 2.1.1 Relationship between the CP and the CPS
Relationship between the CP and the CPS Controls

controls.title: Relationship between the CP and the CPS

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP states the requirements for the issuance and management of certificates issued by the CAs, and requirements for the operation of the CAs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Certification Practice Statement (CPS) states how the CA(s) implement the requirements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each CA that issues certificates under this CP must have a corresponding approved CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The scope of this U.S. Federal PKI Common Policy Framework CP includes the Certification Authorities used for issuing and managing certificates that are valid to the Federal Common Policy CA on behalf of federal executive branch agencies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP applies to certificates issued to CAs, devices, and federal employees, contractors and other affiliated personnel.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP does not include certificates issued to groups or intended to be shared.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Federal Government departments and agencies operate CAs that are intended to issue certificates for only locally trusted purposes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These CAs do not have a certification path to the Federal Common Policy CA and should not assert the policy OIDs defined in this CP.

groups.title: 2.1.3 Interoperation with CAs Issuing under Different Policies
Interoperation with CAs Issuing under Different Policies Controls

controls.title: Interoperation with CAs Issuing under Different Policies

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Federal Government agency CAs may perform cross-certification with either the Federal Common Policy CA or Federal Bridge CA at their discretion.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Interoperability may also be achieved through other means, such as trust lists.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This is the X.509 Certificate Policy for the U.S. Federal PKI Common Policy Framework.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued in accordance with this CP must assert at least one of the following OIDs in the certificate policies extension:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-policy                   | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 6}  |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-hardware                 | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 7}  |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-devices                  | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 8}  |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-devicesHardware          | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 36} |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-authentication           | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 13} |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-cardAuth                 | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 17} |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning       | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 39} |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth          | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 40} |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 41} |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication      | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 45} |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth            | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 46} |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning      | ::= {2 16 840 1 101 3 2 1 3 47} |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA certificates may contain a subset of these OIDs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber certificates must contain an appropriate policy OID as described in the following tables:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates asserting the following policies are issued to Human Subscribers and are limited to use with PIV credentials by FIPS 201.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |PIV Authentication certificate with the private key on a PIV credential|id-fpki-common-authentication|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Derived PIV Authentication certificate issued in accordance with NIST SP 800-157 where the private key is not on a PIV credential|id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware or id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth as appropriate |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Digital signature certificate with the private key on a PIV credential|id-fpki-common-hardware or id-fpki-common-high|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Digital signature certificate with the private key not on a PIV credential|id-fpki-common-policy, id-fpki-common-hardware, or id-fpki-common-high|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Key Management certificate, whether or not on a PIV credential|id-fpki-common-policy, id-fpki-common-hardware, or id-fpki-common-high |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Common PIV-I Authentication certificate with the private key on a federally-issued PIV-I credential|id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Other authentication certificate|id-fpki-common-policy, id-fpki-common-hardware, or id-fpki-common-high|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements associated with id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication are identical to id-fpki-common-authentication, with the exception of the need for a National Agency Check with Inquiries (NACI) and associated favorable adjudication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Appendix A for additional comparisons between PIV and Common PIV-I credentials.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates asserting the following policies are issued to Device Subscribers and are limited to use with PIV credentials by FIPS 201.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Card Authentication certificate with the private key on a PIV credential                                    | id-fpki-common-cardAuth           |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Content Signing certificate used to sign PIV data objects in accordance with \[FIPS 201\] or \[SP 800-157\] | id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements associated with id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning are identical to id-fpki-common-devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Hardware except where specifically noted in the text.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates asserting the following policies may be issued to devices or software systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | FIPS 140 Level 2 or higher hardware cryptographic modules                                                                   | id-fpki-common-deviceHardware      |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | FIPS 140 Level 1 or higher cryptographic modules                                                                            | id-fpki-common-devices             |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Common PIV-I Card Authentication certificate with the private key on a federally-issued PIV-I credential                    | id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth       |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Common PIV-I Content Signing certificate used to sign federally-issued PIV-I data objects in accordance with \[SP 800-157\] | id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements associated with id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth are identical to id-fpki-common-cardAuth, with the exception of the need for a NACI and associated favorable adjudication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements associated with id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning and are identical to id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning, except where specifically noted in the text.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The following are roles relevant to the administration and operation of CAs under this policy:

groups.title: Federal Chief Information Officers Council Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Federal Chief Information Officer (CIO) Council comprises the Chief Information Officers of all cabinet level departments and other independent agencies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Federal CIO Council has established the framework for the interoperable Federal PKI (FPKI) and oversees the operation of the organizations responsible for governing and promoting its use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In particular, this CP was established under the authority and approval of the Federal CIO Council.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Federal Public Key Infrastructure Policy Authority (FPKIPA) is a sub-council comprised of U.S. Federal Government agency representatives and is chartered under the Federal Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) Council, under the Federal CIO Council.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA owns this certificate policy and represents the interest of the Federal CIOs and Federal CISOs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA is responsible for:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Maintaining this CP,

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Approving the CPS for each CA that issues certificates under this policy,

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Approving the compliance audit report for each CA issuing certificates under this policy, and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensuring continued conformance of each CA that issues certificates under this policy with applicable requirements as a condition for allowing continued participation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIMA is the government program that operates and maintains the Federal PKI operational environment on behalf of the U.S. Government.

groups.title: FPKI Management Authority Program Manager Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Program Manager is the individual within the FPKIMA who has principal responsibility for overseeing the operation of the Federal Common Policy CA, including the required repository, and selecting the FPKIMA staff.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For additional personnel security controls associated with this role see Section 5.3.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A PMA is an individual or group established by an organization or agency for the purpose of ensuring all PKI components are operated in compliance with an appropriate CPS and this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All organizations and agencies operating a PKI under this policy must establish a PMA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The PMA must identify an individual to serve as the liaison for that organization or agency to the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA is the collection of hardware, software and operating personnel that create, sign, and issue public key certificates to Subscribers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA is responsible for issuing and managing certificates including:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The certificate manufacturing process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Publication of certificates

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Revocation of certificates

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Generation and destruction of CA signing keys

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensuring that all aspects of the CA services, operations, and infrastructure related to certificates issued under this CP are performed in accordance with the requirements, representations, and warranties of this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA and related applications (e.g., OCSP, CMS, and KRS) may be hosted on one or more system software layers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Operational and technical security controls including audit logging requirements specified in this CP shall apply to all system software layers, where appropriate and applicable.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Registration Authority (RA) is an entity authorized by the CA to collect, verify, and submit information provided by potential Subscribers for the purpose of issuing public key certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The term RA refers to hardware, software, and individuals that may collectively perform this function.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Individuals fulfilling the RA function are acting in a Trusted Role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA is responsible for:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Control over the registration process.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The identification and authentication process.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Trusted Agent is a person who satisfies all the trustworthiness requirements for an RA and who performs identity proofing as a proxy for the RA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Trusted Agent records information from and verifies biometrics (e.g., photographs) on presented credentials for Applicants who cannot appear in person at an RA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For organizations that have implemented Key Recovery, the applicable requirements for physical, personnel, and procedural security controls, technical security controls, and Compliance Audit are applied as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA requirements are applied to the KED and to the DDS

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - RA requirements are applied to the KRA and KRA automated systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - RA requirements are applied to the KRO and KRO automated systems, when the KRO has privileged access to the KED

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KED is defined as the function, system, or subsystem that maintains the key escrow repository and responds to key registration requests.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KED also responds to key recovery requests from two or more KRAs or self-recovery by a current subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Section 5.2.1.2 contains the description of trusted roles required to operate the KED.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A DDS is an automated system that has the capability to obtain subscriber private keys from the KED or another DDS for data monitoring or other purposes (e.g., email inspection).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DDSs do not provide keys to Subscribers or other Third-Party Requestors.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A DDS has access to escrowed key management keys and must meet all security requirements of the KED as outlined in this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Implementation of a DDS is optional based on organizational operations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A KRA is an individual who is authorized, as specified in the applicable Practice Statement (KRPS or CPS), to recover an escrowed key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRAs send the recovered key to the KRO or directly to the Requestor.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRAs have high level, sensitive access to the KED and are considered Trusted Roles (see Section 5.2.1).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: KRAs can recover large numbers of keys, the number and location of KRAs should be closely controlled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: KRAs may additionally conduct requestor identity verification and authorization validation when KROs are not used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Key Recovery Official (KRO) may optionally be used to support identity verification and authorization validation tasks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: KROs do not have privileged access to the KED.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Requestor is the person or DDS that requests the recovery of a decryption private key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Requestor may be the Subscriber or a third-party (e.g., supervisor, corporate officer or law enforcement officer) authorized to request recovery of a Subscriber’s escrowed key on behalf of the Subscriber or on behalf of the organization.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any individual who can demonstrate a verifiable authority and a need to obtain a recovered key may be considered a Requestor.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An Internal Third-Party Requestor is any Requestor who is in the Subscriber’s supervisory chain or otherwise authorized to obtain the Subscriber’s key for the Issuing Organization (i.e., the organization on behalf of which the CA issues certificates to subscribers).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An External Third-Party Requestor is someone (e.g., investigator) outside the Issuing Organization with a court order or other legal instrument to obtain the decryption private key of the Subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Subscriber is the entity whose name appears as the subject in a certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For this CP and all certificates issued, Subscribers are limited to federal employees, contractors, affiliated personnel, and devices operated by or on behalf of federal agencies.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The term “Subscriber” as used in this document refers only to those who request certificates for uses other than signing and issuing certificates or certificate status information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Subscriber may be referred to as an "Applicant" after applying for a certificate, but before the certificate issuance procedure is completed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There is a subset of Human Subscribers who will be issued role-based certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These certificates identify a specific role on behalf of which the Subscriber is authorized to act rather than the Subscriber’s name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These certificates are issued in the interest of supporting accepted business practices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The role-based certificate can be used in situations where non-repudiation is desired.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Normally, it will be issued in addition to an individual Subscriber certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A specific role may be identified in certificates issued to multiple Subscribers; however, the key pair will be unique to each individual role-based certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For example, there may be four individuals with a certificate issued in the role of “Secretary of Commerce”.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: However, each of the four certificates will have unique keys and certificate serial numbers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Roles for which role-based certificates may be issued are limited to those that are held by a unique individual within an organization (e.g., Chief Information Officer, GSA is a unique individual whereas Program Analyst, GSA is not).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: When determining whether a role-based certificate is authorized, consider whether the role carries inherent authority beyond the job title. Role-based certificates may also be used for individuals on temporary assignment, where the temporary assignment carries an authority not shared by the individuals in their usual occupation, for example: “Watch Commander, Task Force 1”. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A relying party is the entity that relies on the validity of the binding of the Subscriber’s identity to a public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The relying party is responsible for deciding whether or how to check the validity of the certificate by checking the appropriate certificate status information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The relying party can use the certificate to verify the integrity of a digitally signed message, to identify the creator of a message, or to establish confidential communications with the holder of the certificate’s private key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A relying party may use information in the certificate (such as certificate policy identifiers, key usage, or extended key usage) to determine its appropriate usage.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For this certificate policy, the relying party may be any entity that wishes to validate the binding of a public key to the name of a Subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CAs and RAs operating under this CP may require the services of other security, community, and application authorities, such as compliance auditors.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Participating agencies that do not operate a PKI directly must identify one or more Agency Points of Contact (POC) as liaisons to the issuing PKI and the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under this CP may be used for authentication to Federal systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under this CP may also be used for key management, signature, and confidentiality requirements for Federal Government processes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy is intended to support use cases involving unclassified information, which can include sensitive unclassified data protected pursuant to federal statutes and regulations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Agencies make risk-informed decisions when using certificates to manage the identities of federal systems and users by evaluating the environment, associated threats, and vulnerabilities in determining the level of risk they are willing to accept based on the sensitivity or significance of the information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This evaluation is done by agencies for each application and is not controlled by this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates that assert id-fpki-common-cardAuth or id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth must only be used to authenticate the hardware token containing the associated private key and must not be interpreted as authenticating the presenter or holder of the token.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates intended for code signing are not permitted under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA is responsible for all aspects of this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Contact information for the support and co-chairs for the FPKIPA is [](mailto:fpki@gsa.gov).

groups.title: 2.5.2 Person Determining CPS Suitability for the Policy
Person Determining CPS Suitability for the Policy Controls

controls.title: Person Determining CPS Suitability for the Policy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA must approve the CPS for each CA that issues certificates under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs issuing under this CP are required to meet all requirements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA will not issue waivers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA makes the determination that a CPS complies with this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA and RA must operate under an approved CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RA practices are documented in the CPS or an associated Registration Practices Statement (RPS).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In each case, the determination process must include an independent compliance auditor’s results and recommendations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 8 for further details.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Appendix B and Appendix C.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The publicly accessible repository system must be designed and implemented so as to provide 99% availability overall and limit scheduled down-time to 0.5% annually.

groups.title: 3.2.0 Publication of Certificates and Certificate Status
Publication of Certificates and Certificate Status Controls

controls.title: Publication of Certificates and Certificate Status

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CAs that issue CA certificates must publish all CA certificates it issues in a file available via a publicly accessible HTTP URI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This URI must be asserted in the Subject Information Access (SIA) extension in all valid certificates issued to the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The file must be a certs-only Cryptographic Message Syntax file that has an extension of .p7c.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: With the exception of self-signed certificates, all CA certificates must be published by the Subject CA in a file available via a publicly accessible HTTP URI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This URI must be asserted in the Authority Information Access (AIA) extension in all valid certificates issued by the Subject CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The file must be:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - a certs-only Cryptographic Message Syntax file that has an extension of .p7c, or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - a single DER encoded certificate that has an extension of .cer

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The certs-only Cryptographic Message Syntax format is preferred as it allows flexibility for inclusion of multiple certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CAs that issue certificates under this policy must publish the latest CRL covering all unexpired certificates via a publicly accessible HTTP URI until such time as all issued certificates have expired.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This URI must be asserted in the CRL distribution point extension of all certificates issued by that CA, with the exception of Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) responder certificates that include the id-pkix-ocsp-nocheck extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Certificate Status Server (CSS) provides status information about certificates on behalf of a CA through on-line transactions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs must include a CSS in the form of a delegated OCSP service, as described in \[RFC 6960\], to provide on-line status information for Subscriber certificates via a publicly accessible HTTP URI in the AIA extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The operations of the OCSP service are within the scope of this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Pre-generated OCSP responses may be created by the CSS and distributed to OCSP servers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: OCSP responses, like CRLs, are publicly distributable data.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: OCSP servers that lack OCSP response signing capability have the same security requirements as a repository hosting CRLs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: OCSP services that are locally trusted, as described in \[RFC 6960\], are not covered by this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All certificates must contain only valid Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) that are publicly accessible by relying parties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP must be publicly available on [](http://www.idmanagement.gov/).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CPS and annual PKI Compliance Audit Letter for the Federal Common Policy CA are publicly available on [](http://www.idmanagement.gov/).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Other CAs operating under this policy should make available a redacted CPS and annual PKI Compliance Audit Letter in their organization’s public repository.

groups.title: Time or Frequency of Publication Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP and any subsequent changes must be made publicly available within thirty (30) days of approval.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Publication requirements for CRLs are provided in Sections 4.9.7 and 4.9.12.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Repositories hosting CA certificates, CRLs, and pre-generated OCSP responses (if implemented) must be publicly accessible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information not intended for modification or public dissemination must be protected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each CPS must detail what information in the repository is exempt from automatic availability and to whom, and under which conditions the restricted information may be made available.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Posted certificates, CRLs, and pre-generated OCSP responses may be replicated in additional repositories for performance enhancement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP establishes requirements for both subject distinguished names and subject alternative names.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must assign X.501 distinguished names to all Subscriber certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These distinguished names are comprised of a base distinguished name (Base DN) and additional relative distinguished names (RDNs).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Base DNs may be in either of two forms: a geo-political name or an Internet domain component name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All geo-political distinguished names must use one of the following Base DNs:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, ou=department, ou=agency, \[ou=*structural_container*\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, ou=department, \[ou=*structural_container*\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - C=US, o=U.S. Government, ou=agency, \[ou=*structural_container*\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organizational units department and agency appear when applicable and are used to specify the federal entity that employs the Human Subscriber or owns the device.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At least one of these organizational units must appear in the DN.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Distinguished names based on Internet domain component names must use the following Base DN:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - dc=gov, dc=org0, \[dc=org1\], …, \[ dc=orgN\], \[o=organization\], \[ou=*structural_container*\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, the org0 domain component must appear in the Base DN.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The org1 to orgN domain components appear, in order, when applicable, and are used to specify the federal entity that employs the Human Subscriber or owns the device.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The additional organizational unit *structural_container* in either the geo-political or Internet domain Base DN form is permitted to support local directory requirements, such as differentiation between Human Subscribers and Device Subscribers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This organizational unit may not be employed to further differentiate between subcomponents within an agency.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The distinguished name of the Human Subscriber must include a common name (CN) using one of the following formats:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Base DN, CN=nickname lastname

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Base DN, CN=firstname initial.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: lastname

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Base DN, CN=firstname initial lastname

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Base DN, CN=firstname middlename lastname

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Base DN, CN=lastname.firstname.middlename

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the first common name format, nickname may be the Human Subscriber’s first name, a form of the first name, middle name, or pseudonym (e.g., Buck) by which the Subscriber is generally known.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A generational qualifier, such as “Sr.” or “III”, or agency specific identifiers (e.g., CN=Giants.John.Gregory.1234567890) may be appended to any of the common name formats specified above.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Additional certificate qualifiers may be appended to the common name in order to provide additional context to the certificate’s intended usage.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The qualifier must be preceded by a space followed by a hyphen (e.g., CN=John G. Giants -ENC).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Distinguished names assigned to federal contractors and other affiliated persons must follow one of the name forms identified above with (affiliate) appended to the end of the common name (e.g., CN=John G. Giants (affiliate)).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA may supplement any of the distinguished name forms for Human Subscribers specified in this section by including a dnQualifier, serial number, or user id.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When any of these are included, they may appear:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - as part of a multi-valued RDN with the common name, or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - as a distinct RDN that follows the RDN containing the common name

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Role-based signature certificates may be issued under id-fpki-common-hardware or id-fpki-common-high (see Section 1.3.4).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For these certificates, the common name specifies the role, as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CN=role \[, department/agency\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where the \[department/agency\] is implicit in the role (e.g., Secretary of Commerce), it should be omitted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where the role alone is ambiguous (e.g., Chief Information Officer) the department/agency must be present in the common name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organizational information in the common name must match that in the organizational unit attributes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: In the case of “Chief Information Officer”, use of department/agency in the common name is redundant but is included for usability purposes. Display of the common name is widely supported in applications. Other attributes may or may not be presented to users. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Device Subscriber distinguished names must take the following form:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Base DN, CN=device name

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: where device name is a descriptive name for the device.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning or id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning is asserted, the certificate’s subject distinguished name must indicate the organization administering the credential issuance system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When id-fpki-common-cardAuth is asserted, the certificate’s subject distinguished name must take one of the following forms:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Base DN, serialNumber=FASC-N

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Base DN, serialNumber=UUID

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth is asserted, the certificate’s subject distinguished name must take the following form:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Base DN, serialNumber=UUID

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP does not restrict the subject distinguished names of CA certificates and Delegated OCSP Responder certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: However, CA certificates and Delegated OCSP Responder certificates must have subject distinguished names.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA and Delegated OCSP Responder certificate distinguished names may be either a geo-political name or an Internet domain component name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Geo-political distinguished names must be composed of any combination of the following attributes: country; organization; organizational unit; and common name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Internet domain component names are composed of the following attributes: domain component; organizational unit; and common name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA subject distinguished names may or may not include a common name, for example:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: > Base DN, OU=Certification Authorities, OU=Agency CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If included, the common name in the CA certificates should describe the issuer, such as:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: > Base DN, OU=Certification Authorities, CN=AgencyX CA-3

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under id-fpki-common-authentication or id-fpki-common-cardAuth must include a subject alternative name extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The subject alternative name extension must include both:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the pivFASC-N name type \[FIPS 201\], the value of which must be the FASC-N \[PACS\] of the subject’s PIV credential; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - a UUID encoded as a URI as specified in Section 3 of \[RFC 4122\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under id-fpki-common-cardAuth must not include any other name in the subject alternative name extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware and id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth must include a subject alternative name extension that includes:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - a UUID encoded as a URI as specified in Section 3 of \[RFC 4122\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - for derived PIV, UUID is unique per certificate

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth must not include any other name in the subject alternative name extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber certificates that contain id-kp-emailProtection in the EKU must include a subject alternative name extension that includes a rfc822Name.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For Device Subscriber certificates that assert serverAuth in the Extended Key Usage:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A subject alternative name of type dNSName must be included.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Wildcard domain names are permitted in the dNSName values only if all sub-domains covered by the wildcard fall within the same application, cloud service, or system accreditation boundary within the scope of the sponsoring agency.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Wildcards must not be used in subdomains that host more than one distinct application platform.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of third-level agency wildcards, (e.g., \*.\[agency\].gov), must be prohibited to reduce the likelihood that a certificate will overlap multiple systems or services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Third level wildcards are permitted for dNSName dedicated to a specific application (e.g., \*.\[application_name\].gov).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Before requesting a serverAuth certificate containing a wildcard, the sponsoring agency must provide evidence to the issuing CA that the scope of the certificate does not now and will not infringe on other agency applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Section 3.1 Practice Note: The FASC-N \[PACS\] consists of 40 decimal digits that are encoded as a 25-byte binary value. This 25-byte binary value may be encoded directly into the pivFASC-N name type in the subject alternative name extension, but when included in the subject distinguished name the FASC-N must be encoded as a PrintableString that is at most 64 characters long. This policy does not mandate any particular method for encoding the FASC-N within the serial number attribute as long as the same encoding method is used for all certificates issued by a CA. Acceptable methods for encoding the FASC-N within the serial number attribute include encoding the 25-byte binary value as 50 bytes of ASCII HEX or encoding the 40 decimal digits as 40 bytes of ASCII decimal. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Section 3.1 Practice Note: When the UUID appears in the subject alternative name extension of a certificate, it must be encoded as a uniformResourceIdentifier as specified in Section 3 of \[RFC 4122\]. An example of a UUID encoded as a URI, from RFC 4122, is “urn:uuid:f81d4fae-7dec-11d0-a765-00a0c91e6bf6”. This policy does not mandate any particular method for encoding the UUID within the serial number attribute as long as the same encoding method is used for all certificates issued by the CA and it is encoded as a PrintableString that is at most 64 characters long. However, it is recommended that the string representation from Section 3 of \[RFC 4122\] be used. An example would be “f81d4fae-7dec-11d0-a765-00a0c91e6bf6”. |

groups.title: 4.1.1 Need for Names to Be Meaningful
Need for Names to Be Meaningful Controls

controls.title: Need for Names to Be Meaningful

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber certificates are meaningful only if the names that appear in the certificates can be understood and used by relying parties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Names used in the certificates must identify in a meaningful way the Subscriber to which they are assigned.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The common name in the distinguished name must represent the Subscriber in a way that is easily understandable for humans.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For Human Subscribers, this will typically be a legal name, see Section 3.1.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The subject name in CA certificates must match the issuer name in certificates issued by the subject, as required by \[RFC 5280\].

groups.title: Anonymity or Pseudonymity of Subscribers Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CA must not issue anonymous certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Role-based certificates may be issued by the CA to support internal operations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs may also issue role-based certificates that identify subjects by their organizational roles, as described in Section 3.1.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA certificates must not contain anonymous or pseudonymous identities.

groups.title: 4.1.3 Rules for Interpreting Various Name Forms
Rules for Interpreting Various Name Forms Controls

controls.title: Rules for Interpreting Various Name Forms

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Rules for interpreting distinguished name forms are specified in \[X.501\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Rules for interpreting e-mail addresses are specified in \[RFC 5322\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Rules for interpreting the pivFASC-N name type are specified in \[PACS\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Name uniqueness for certificates issued by each CA must be enforced.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each CA and its associated RAs must enforce name uniqueness within the X.500 namespace.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When other name forms are used, they too must be allocated such that name uniqueness is ensured for certificates issued by that CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Name uniqueness is not violated when multiple certificates are issued to the same entity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: For distinguished names, name uniqueness is enforced for the entire name rather than a particular attribute (e.g., the common name). |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CPS must identify the method for the assignment of subject names.

groups.title: 4.1.5 Recognition, Authentication, and Role of Trademarks
Recognition, Authentication, and Role of Trademarks Controls

controls.title: Recognition, Authentication, and Role of Trademarks

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must not issue a certificate knowing that it infringes the trademark of another.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA must resolve disputes involving names and trademarks.

groups.title: 4.2.0 Method to Prove Possession of Private Key
Method to Prove Possession of Private Key Controls

controls.title: Method to Prove Possession of Private Key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must verify the Applicant has possession of the private key that corresponds to the public key in the certificate request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As an example, for signature keys this may be done by the Applicant using its private key to sign a value supplied by the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must then validate the signature using the Applicant’s public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA may allow other mechanisms that are at least as secure as those cited here.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the case where key generation is performed under the CA or RA’s direct control, proof of possession is not required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (e.g., key management certificates generated in a system allowing key escrow.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requests for CA certificates must include the CA name, address, and documentation of the existence of the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Before issuing CA certificates, an authority for the issuing CA must verify the information provided by the requesting organization, in addition to the authenticity of the requesting representative and the representative’s authorization to act in the name of the organization.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Before issuing subscriber certificates on behalf of an organization, the issuing CA must verify the authority of requesting representatives.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requests for Third-Party recovery of Subscriber keys must include validation of the individual’s authority to act on behalf of the requesting organization.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For each certificate issued, the CA must authenticate the identity of the individual requester.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Procedures used by agencies to authenticate the identity of their own personnel and affiliates may be more stringent than that set forth below.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When this is the case, the agency procedures for authentication of the identity of personnel must apply in addition to the requirements in this section.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA must ensure that the Applicant’s identity information is verified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, procedures for employees must include the following steps:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  Verify that a request for certificate issuance to the Applicant was submitted by agency management.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  Verify Applicant’s employment through use of official agency records.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  Establish Applicant’s identity by in-person or supervised remote[^1] proofing before the RA or trusted agent, as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  The Applicant presents a government-issued form of identification (e.g., an Agency ID badge, a passport, or driver’s license) as proof of identity, and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  The RA examines the presented credential for biometric data that can be linked to the Applicant (e.g., a photograph on the credential itself or a securely linked photograph of Applicant), and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  The credential presented in step 3a above must be verified by the RA for currency and legitimacy (e.g., the agency ID is verified as valid).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Typically, this is accomplished by querying a database maintained by the organization that issued the credential, but other equivalent methods may be used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 4.  Record and maintain a biometric of the Applicant (e.g., a photograph or fingerprint) by the RA or CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (Handwritten signatures and other behavioral characteristics are not accepted as biometrics for the purposes of this policy.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This establishes an audit trail for dispute resolution.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For contractors and other affiliated personnel, the procedures must include the following steps:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  Verify that a request for certificate issuance to the Applicant was submitted by an authorized sponsoring agency employee (e.g., contracting officer or contracting officer’s technical representative).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  Verify sponsoring agency employee’s identity and employment as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  A digitally signed request from the sponsoring agency employee, verified by a currently valid employee signature certificate issued by an agency CA, may be accepted as proof of both employment and identity,

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  Authentication of the sponsoring agency employee with a valid employee PIV-authentication certificate issued by the agency may be accepted as proof of both employment and identity, or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  In-person or supervised remote identity proofing of the sponsoring agency employee may be established before the registration authority as specified in employee authentication above and employment validated through use of the official agency records.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  Establish Applicant’s identity by in-person or supervised remote proofing before the registration authority or trusted agent, as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  The Applicant presents a government-issued form of identification (e.g., an Agency ID badge, a passport, or driver’s license) as proof of identity, and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  The RA examines the presented credential for biometric data that can be linked to the Applicant (e.g., a photograph on the credential itself or a securely linked photograph of Applicant), and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  The credential presented in step 3a above must be verified by the RA for currency and legitimacy (e.g., the agency ID is verified as valid).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Typically, this is accomplished by querying official records maintained by the organization that issued the credential.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 4.  Record and maintain a biometric of the Applicant (e.g., a photograph or fingerprint) by the RA or CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (Handwritten signatures and other behavioral characteristics are not accepted as biometrics for the purposes of this policy.)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This establishes an audit trail for dispute resolution.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event an Applicant is denied a credential based on the results of the identity proofing process, the sponsoring agency must provide a mechanism for appeal or redress of the decision.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Additionally, the RA must record the process that was followed for issuance of each certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The process documentation and authentication requirements must include the following:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The identity of the person performing the authentication and either:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A signed declaration by that person that he or she verified the identity of the Applicant using the format set forth at \[28 U.S.C. 1746\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (declaration under penalty of perjury); or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - An auditable record identifying the person performing the identification and recording the assertion that he or she verified the identity of the Applicant.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Unique identifying number(s) from the ID(s) of the Applicant, or a facsimile of the ID(s);

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The biometric of the Applicant;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The date and time of the verification; and either:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - An auditable record indicating the applicant accepted the certificate; or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A declaration of identity signed by the Applicant using a handwritten signature or appropriate digital signature and performed in the presence of the person performing the identity authentication, using the format set forth at \[28 U.S.C. 1746\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (declaration under penalty of perjury).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth, and id-fpki-common-cardAuth, identity must be verified in accordance with the requirements specified for issuing PIV in Section 2.7 of \[FIPS 201\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At id-fpki-common-High, id-fpki-common-authentication, and id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, the Applicant must appear at the RA in person or via supervised remote.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For id-fpki-common-policy and id-fpki-common-hardware, RAs may accept authentication of an Applicant’s identity attested to and documented by a trusted agent, assuming agency identity requirements are otherwise satisfied.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Authentication by a trusted agent does not relieve the RA of its responsibility to verify required procedures were followed as described above.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware and id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth, identity must be verified in accordance with the requirements specified for issuing derived credentials in \[SP 800-157\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, the Applicant must appear at the RA in person or via supervised remote.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA or CA must:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1)  Verify that the request for certificate issuance to the Applicant was submitted by an authorized agency employee.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2)  Use the PKI-AUTH authentication mechanism from Section 6 of \[FIPS 201\] to verify that the PIV Authentication certificate on the Applicant’s PIV credential is valid and that the Applicant is in possession of the corresponding private key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3)  Maintain a copy of the Applicant’s PIV Authentication certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Seven days after issuing the derived credential, the CA should recheck the revocation status of the PIV Authentication certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This step can detect use of a compromised PIV credential to obtain a derived credential.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued under id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, the Applicant must appear in person or via supervised remote to present the PIV credential and perform the PKI-AUTH authentication mechanism.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA must perform a one-to-one comparison of the Applicant against biometric data stored on the PIV credential, in accordance with \[SP 800-76\], and must record and maintain the biometric sample used to validate the Applicant.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In cases where a 1:1 biometric match against the biometrics available on the PIV credential or in the chain-of-trust, as defined in \[FIPS 201\] is not possible:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1)  The Applicant must present a government-issued form of identification (e.g., a passport or driver’s license) in addition to the PIV credential, and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2)  The RA must examine the presented credentials for biometric data that can be linked to the Applicant (e.g., a photograph on the credential itself or a securely linked photograph of the Applicant), and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The process documentation and authentication requirements must include the following:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The identity of the person performing the authentication and either:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A signed declaration by that person that he or she verified the identity of the Applicant using the format set forth at \[28 U.S.C. 1746\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (declaration under penalty of perjury); or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - An auditable record linking the authentication of the person performing the identification to their verification of each Applicant.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Unique identifying number(s) from second form of identification of the Applicant, or a facsimile of the ID(s);

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The biometric of the Applicant;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The date and time of the verification;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Some computing and communications devices (routers, firewalls, servers, etc.) and software applications will be named as certificate subjects.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In such cases, the device must have a human sponsor who is affiliated with the agency under which the certificate is being issued.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The sponsor is responsible for providing the following registration information:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Equipment identification (e.g., serial number) or service name (e.g., DNS name) or unique software application name

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Equipment or software application public keys

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Equipment or software application authorizations and attributes (if any are to be included in the certificate)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Contact information to enable the CA or RA to communicate with the sponsor when required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These certificates must be issued only to authorized devices under the subscribing organization’s control.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the case a human sponsor is changed, the new sponsor must review the status of each device under his/her sponsorship to ensure it is still authorized to receive certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CPS must describe procedures to ensure that certificate accountability is maintained.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 9.6.3 for Subscriber responsibilities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Before issuing a certificate with a wildcard character (\*) in a common name or subject alternative name of type dNSName, the CA must establish and follow a documented procedure to ensure that the wildcard does not fall immediately to the left of an agency or organization name, but is qualified down to a unique application, server, or server farm under control of the sponsor’s organization (see Section 3.1.1).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The device sponsor must demonstrate that the domain name requested is entirely within the namespace to be covered by the wildcard certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The identity of the sponsor must be authenticated by:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verification of digitally signed messages sent from the sponsor using a certificate issued under this policy; or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - In-person or supervised remote registration by the sponsor, with the identity of the sponsor confirmed in accordance with the requirements of Section 3.2.3.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All Subscriber information included in certificates must be verified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must validate the requestor’s authority to act in the name of the organization before issuing organizational certificates, such as CA certificates, role-based certificates, or content signing certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For example, before issuing role-based certificates, the CA must validate that the individual either holds that role or has been delegated the authority to sign on behalf of the role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In accordance with Section 3.2.3.2, all requests for device certificates in the name of an organization, must be digitally signed by the sponsor.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition, the CPS must specify a process by which an organization identifies the individuals who may request certificates that assert organizational authority.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If an organization specifies, in writing, the individuals who may request a certificate, then the CA must not accept any certificate requests that are outside this specification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must provide an Applicant with a list of the organization’s authorized certificate requestors upon the Applicant’s verified written request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA must determine the interoperability criteria for CAs operating under this policy.

groups.title: 4.2 Identification and Authentication for Re-Key Requests
4.3.0 Identification and Authentication for Routine Re-key
Identification and Authentication for Routine Re-key Controls

controls.title: Identification and Authentication for Routine Re-key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA certificate re-key must follow the same procedures as initial certificate issuance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PIV subscriber's identity should be established through the use of a current signature key, except that identity must be re-established and biometrics re-collected through an in-person or supervised remote registration at least every twelve years.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event a PIV Subscriber's signature key cannot be used, identity may be verified through the use of biometrics on file through the chain of trust defined in \[FIPS 201\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For re-key of Human Subscriber certificates issued under id-fpki-common-high, identity may be established through use of current signature key, except that identity must be established through an in-person registration process at least once every three years from the time of initial registration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For id-fpki-common-policy, id-fpki-common-hardware, id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth, and id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, a Human Subscriber’s identity may be established through use of current signature key, except that identity must be re-established through an in-person or supervised remote registration process at least once every twelve years from the time of initial registration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For re-key of Subscriber certificates issued under id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth and id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, the department or agency must verify that the Subscriber is eligible to have a PIV credential (i.e., PIV credential is not terminated).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For re-key of Subscriber certificates issued under id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware, identity must be established via mutual authentication between the issuer and the cryptographic module containing the current key, if the new key will be stored in the same cryptographic module as the current key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identity must be established through the initial registration process per Section 3.2 if the new key will be stored in a different cryptographic module than the current key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For Device Subscribers, identity may be established through the use of the device’s current signature key or the signature key of the device’s human sponsor.

groups.title: 4.3.1 Identification and Authentication for Re-key after Revocation
Identification and Authentication for Re-key after Revocation Controls

controls.title: Identification and Authentication for Re-key after Revocation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event of certificate revocation, issuance of a new certificate must require that the Applicant go through the initial registration process per Section 3.2 above, unless identity can be verified through the use of biometrics on file through the chain of trust defined in \[FIPS 201\].

groups.title: 4.3 Identification and Authentication for Revocation Request
Identification and Authentication for Revocation Request Controls

controls.title: Identification and Authentication for Revocation Request

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Revocation requests must be authenticated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Note that revocation requests may be digitally signed using a certificate's private key, regardless of whether or not the private key has been compromised.

groups.title: 4.4 Identification and Authentication for Key Recovery Requests

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This section addresses the requirements for authentication of a Third-Party Requestor, i.e., a Requestor other than the Subscriber themself.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements for authentication, when the Requestor is the Subscriber, are addressed in Section 3.3.1 or Section 3.2.3.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identity authentication must be commensurate with the assurance level of the certificate associated with the key being recovered.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identity must be established using one of the following methods:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Procedures specified in Section 3.2.3 for authentication of an individual identity during initial registration for the specified certificate policy assurance level (an assurance level equal to or greater than the assurance level of the certificate whose corresponding private key is being recovered).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificate-based authentication (e.g., digitally signed e-mail or client-authenticated TLS) that can be verified using current, valid (i.e., un-revoked) public key certificates at the requested certificate policy assurance level (an assurance level equal to or greater than the assurance level of the certificate whose corresponding private key is being recovered).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRA or KRO must verify the identity and authorization of the Requestor prior to initiating the key recovery request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Subscriber identity must be established as specified in Section 3.3.1 above.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Alternatively, if the authentication cannot be verified using the public key certificates issued by the associated PKI and for at least the given certificate policy assurance level, then the identity validation can use the steps outlined in Section 3.2.3.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For automated self-recovery, the Subscriber must be authenticated to the KED using a valid public key certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The assurance level of the Subscriber certificate must be equal to or greater than that of the certificate whose corresponding private key is being recovered.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRA must authenticate to the KED or DDS directly or using a public key certificate issued by the associated PKI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The assurance level of the certificate must be the same as or greater than that of the certificate whose corresponding private key is being recovered and must meet the requirements of an RA credential.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRO must authenticate to the KRA using a public key certificate issued by the associated PKI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The assurance level of the certificate must be the same as or greater than that of the certificate whose corresponding private key is being recovered and must meet the requirements of an RA credential.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The DDS must authenticate to the KED directly using a public key certificate issued by the associated PKI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The assurance level of the certificate must be the same as or greater than that of the highest assurance level encryption certificates issued by the associated PKI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Certificate application process must provide sufficient information to:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Establish the Applicant’s authorization by the employing or sponsoring agency to obtain a certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 3.2.3 for requirements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Establish and record the identity of the Applicant.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 3.2.3 for requirements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Obtain the Applicant’s public key and verify the Applicant’s possession of the private key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 3.2.3 for requirements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verify the information included in the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These steps may be performed in any order, but all must be completed before certificate issuance.

groups.title: 5.1.0 Who Can Submit a Certificate Application
Who Can Submit a Certificate Application Controls

controls.title: Who Can Submit a Certificate Application

parts.name: statement
