parts.prose: | Type of Certificate                          | Who can submit an application?                                                              |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | CA and Delegated OCSP Responder Certificates | Authorized representative of the CA                                                         |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Human Subscriber Certificate                 | An authorized agency official, the Applicant, or a Trusted Agent on behalf of the Applicant |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Device Certificate                           | The human sponsor of the device                                                             |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All communications supporting the certificate application and issuance process must be authenticated and protected from modification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Communications may be electronic or out-of-band.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any electronic communication of shared secrets must be protected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where electronic communications are used, cryptographic mechanisms commensurate with the strength of the public/private key pair must be used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Out-of-band communications must protect the confidentiality and integrity of the data.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers are responsible for providing accurate information on their certificate applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information in certificate applications must be verified as accurate before certificates are issued.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each CPS must specify procedures to verify information in certificate applications.

groups.title: Performing Identification and Authentication Functions Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The identification and authentication of the Subscriber must meet the requirements specified for Subscriber authentication as specified in Sections 3.2 and 3.3 of this CP.

groups.title: 5.2.1 Approval or Rejection of Certificate Applications
Approval or Rejection of Certificate Applications Controls

controls.title: Approval or Rejection of Certificate Applications

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA may approve or reject requests for certificates from the Federal Common Policy CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber certificate approval or rejection is at the discretion of the Agency.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs must reject a certificate request if the requested public key has a known weak private key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Public key parameters generation and quality checking must be conducted in accordance with \[NIST SP 800-89\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Key validity must be confirmed in accordance with \[NIST SP 800-56A\].

groups.title: Time to Process Certificate Applications Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificate applications must be processed and a certificate issued within 90 days of identity verification.

groups.title: CA Actions During Certificate Issuance Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Upon receiving the request, the CAs/RAs will:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verify the identity of the requestor.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verify the authority of the requestor and the integrity of the information in the certificate request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Build and sign a certificate if all certificate requirements have been met (in the case of an RA, have the CA sign the certificate).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Make the certificate available to the Subscriber after confirming that the Subscriber has formally acknowledged the obligations described in Section 9.6.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The certificate request may already contain a certificate built by either the RA or the Subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This certificate will not be signed until all verifications and modifications, if any, have been completed to the CA’s satisfaction.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All attribute information received from a prospective Subscriber must be verified before inclusion in a certificate.

groups.title: 5.3.1 Notification to Subscriber by the CA of Issuance of Certificate
Notification to Subscriber by the CA of Issuance of Certificate Controls

controls.title: Notification to Subscriber by the CA of Issuance of Certificate

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must inform the Subscriber (or other certificate subject) of the creation of a certificate and make the certificate available to the Subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For device certificates, the CA must inform the human sponsor.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Before Human Subscribers can use their private keys, they must accept the responsibilities defined in Section 9.6.3 by accepting the Subscriber agreement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CA certificates issued by the Federal Common Policy CA, failure to object to the certificate or its contents constitutes acceptance of the CA certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued to Subscribers, a signed Subscriber agreement or auditable record of acceptance constitutes acceptance of the certificates.

groups.title: 5.4.1 Publication of the Certificate by the CA
Publication of the Certificate by the CA Controls

controls.title: Publication of the Certificate by the CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As specified in Section 2.1, all CA certificates must be published in repositories.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates that contain the FASC-N and/or UUID in the subject alternative name extension, such as PIV Authentication Certificates, must not be distributed via public repositories (e.g., via LDAP or HTTP).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy makes no other stipulation regarding publication of Subscriber certificates.

groups.title: 5.4.2 Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities
Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities Controls

controls.title: Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA must be notified at least two weeks prior to issuance of a CA certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition, notification must be provided to the FPKIPA when the CA certificate is published.

groups.title: 5.5.0 Subscriber Private Key and Certificate Usage
Subscriber Private Key and Certificate Usage Controls

controls.title: Subscriber Private Key and Certificate Usage

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The intended scope of usage for a private key is specified through certificate extensions, including the key usage and extended key usage extensions, in the associated certificate.

groups.title: 5.5.1 Relying Party Public key and Certificate Usage
Relying Party Public key and Certificate Usage Controls

controls.title: Relying Party Public key and Certificate Usage

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Common Policy-issued certificates specify restrictions on use through certificate extensions, including the basic constraints and key usage extensions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs provide certificate status information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Relying parties should process certificate and status information as specified in \[X.509\] when relying on Common Policy certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Renewing a certificate means creating a new certificate with a new serial number where all certificate subject information, including the subject public key and subject key identifier, remain unchanged.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The new certificate may have an extended validity period and may include new issuer information (e.g., different CRL distribution point, AIA and/or be signed with a different issuer key).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once renewed, the old certificate may or may not be revoked but must not be reused for requesting further renewals, re-keys, or modifications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber certificates issued under this policy must not be renewed, except during recovery from CA key compromise (see Section 5.7.3).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In such cases, the renewed certificate must expire as specified in the original Subscriber certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA certificates and Delegated OCSP responder certificates may be renewed so long as the aggregated lifetime of the private key does not exceed the requirements specified in Section 6.3.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For the Federal Common Policy CA, the FPKIMA may request renewal of CA certificates it issues.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For other CA certificates and Delegated OCSP responder certificates, the corresponding operating authority may request renewal.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a CA re-keys, it may renew the certificates it has issued.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When certificates are renewed as a result of CA key compromise, as described in Section 4.6.1, the CA or RA must verify all certificates issued since the date of compromise were issued appropriately.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the certificate cannot be verified, then it must not be renewed.

groups.title: 5.6.3 Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber
Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber Controls

controls.title: Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As specified in Section 4.3.2.

groups.title: 5.6.4 Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Renewal Certificate
Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Renewal Certificate Controls

controls.title: Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Renewal Certificate

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued by the Federal Common Policy CA, failure to object to the renewal of the certificate or its contents constitutes acceptance of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other CAs operating under this policy, no stipulation.

groups.title: 5.6.5 Publication of the Renewal Certificate by the CA
Publication of the Renewal Certificate by the CA Controls

controls.title: Publication of the Renewal Certificate by the CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CA certificates must be published as specified in Section 4.4.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy makes no stipulation regarding publication of Subscriber certificates, except as noted in Section 9.4.3.

groups.title: 5.6.6 Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities
Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities Controls

controls.title: Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As specified in Section 4.4.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Re-key is identical to renewal except the new certificate must have a different subject public key and serial number.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once re-keyed, the old certificate may or may not be revoked, but must not be reused for requesting further renewals, re-keys, or modifications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Circumstances requiring certificate re-key include nearing the maximum usage period of a private key, certificate expiration, loss or compromise, issuance of a new hardware token, and hardware token failure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Section 6.3.2 establishes maximum usage periods for private keys for both CAs and Subscribers.

groups.title: 5.7.1 Who May Request Certification of a New Public Key
Who May Request Certification of a New Public Key Controls

controls.title: Who May Request Certification of a New Public Key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CA certificates and Delegated OCSP responder certificates, the corresponding operating authority may request re-key of its own certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers with a currently valid certificate may request re-key of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs and RAs may request certification of a new public key on behalf of a Subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The human sponsor of a device may request re-key of the device certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers must identify themselves for the purpose of re-keying as required in Section 3.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA or RA must verify the information provided prior to issuing the new certificate as specified in Section 4.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Digitally signed Subscriber re-key requests must be validated before the re-key requests are processed.

groups.title: 5.7.3 Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber
Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber Controls

controls.title: Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As specified in Section 4.3.2.

groups.title: 5.7.4 Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Re-keyed Certificate
Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Re-keyed Certificate Controls

controls.title: Conduct Constituting Acceptance of a Re-keyed Certificate

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued by the Federal Common Policy CA, failure to object to the certificate or its contents constitutes acceptance of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other CAs operating under this policy, no stipulation.

groups.title: 5.7.5 Publication of the Re-keyed Certificate by the CA
Publication of the Re-keyed Certificate by the CA Controls

controls.title: Publication of the Re-keyed Certificate by the CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CA certificates must be published as specified in Section 4.4.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy makes no stipulation regarding publication of Subscriber certificates, except as noted in Section 9.4.3.

groups.title: 5.7.6 Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities
Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities Controls

controls.title: Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As specified in Section 4.4.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Modifying a certificate means creating a new certificate that has the same or a different key and a different serial number, and that differs in one or more other fields from the old certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once modified, the old certificate may or may not be revoked, but must not be reused for requesting further renewals, re-keys, or modifications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA certificates and Delegated OCSP responder certificates whose characteristics have changed (e.g., assert new policy OID) may be modified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The new certificate may have the same or a different subject public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A certificate associated with a Subscriber whose characteristics have changed (e.g., name change due to marriage) may be modified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The new certificate must have a different subject public key.

groups.title: Who May Request Certificate Modification Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CA certificates and Delegated OCSP responder certificates, the corresponding operating authority may request modification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers with a currently valid certificate may request modification of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The human sponsor of a device may request modification of the device certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs and RAs may request certificate modification on behalf of a Subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Proof of all subject information changes (e.g., name changes due to marriage) must be provided to the RA or other designated agent.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA or RA must verify the information provided prior to issuing the new certificate as specified in Section 4.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If an individual’s authorizations or privileges change, such that the modified certificate indicates a reduction in privileges and authorizations, the old certificate must be revoked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the modified certificate is issued with a new (different) public key, the additional requirements specified in Section 4.7.3 must also apply.

groups.title: 5.8.3 Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber
Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber Controls

controls.title: Notification of New Certificate Issuance to Subscriber

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As specified in Section 4.3.2.

groups.title: 5.8.4 Conduct Constituting Acceptance of Modified Certificate
Conduct Constituting Acceptance of Modified Certificate Controls

controls.title: Conduct Constituting Acceptance of Modified Certificate

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued by the Federal Common Policy CA, failure to object to the certificate or its contents constitutes acceptance of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other CAs operating under this policy, no stipulation.

groups.title: 5.8.5 Publication of the Modified Certificate by the CA
Publication of the Modified Certificate by the CA Controls

controls.title: Publication of the Modified Certificate by the CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CA certificates must be published as specified in Section 4.4.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This policy makes no stipulation regarding publication of Subscriber certificates, except as noted in Section 9.4.3.

groups.title: 5.8.6 Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities
Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities Controls

controls.title: Notification of Certificate Issuance by the CA to Other Entities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As specified in Section 4.4.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Revocation requests must be authenticated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requests to revoke a certificate may be authenticated using that certificate's public key, regardless of whether or not the associated private key has been compromised.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificate suspension for CA certificates is prohibited by this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: However, the use of certificate suspension for Subscriber certificates is permitted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs operating under this policy, the FPKIPA must be notified at least two weeks prior to the revocation of a CA certificate, whenever possible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For emergency revocation, CAs must follow the notification procedures in Section 5.7.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A certificate must be revoked when the binding between the subject and the subject’s public key defined within the certificate is no longer considered valid.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Examples of circumstances that invalidate the binding are:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Identifying information or affiliation components of any names in the certificate becomes invalid.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Examples include:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Subscriber no longer affiliated with sponsoring agency

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - A wild card certificate has been issued with a name where PKI Sponsor does not exercise control of the entire namespace associated with the wild card certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Privilege attributes asserted in the Subscriber’s certificate are reduced.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The Subscriber can be shown to have violated the stipulations of its Subscriber agreement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - There is reason to believe the private key has been compromised.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The Subscriber or other authorized party (as defined in the CPS) asks for his/her certificate to be revoked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The failure of a CA to adequately adhere to the requirements of this CP or the approved CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If it is determined that revocation is required, the associated certificate must be revoked and placed on the CRL.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Revoked certificates must be included on all new publications of the certificate status information until the certificates expire.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If it is determined that a private key used to authorize the issuance of one or more certificates may have been compromised, all certificates directly or indirectly authorized by that private key since the date of actual or suspected compromise must be revoked or must be verified as appropriately issued.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CA may summarily revoke certificates it has issued.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A written notice and brief explanation for the revocation must subsequently be provided to the Subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Subscriber or sponsor of device certificates may request revocation of their own certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA or other authorized agency officials may request the revocation of a Subscriber’s certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must provide Subscribers, Relying Parties, Application Software Suppliers, and other third parties with clear instructions for reporting suspected private key compromise, certificate misuse, or other types of fraud, compromise, misuse, inappropriate conduct, or any other matter related to certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must publicly disclose the instructions through a readily accessible online means.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA can request revocation of any CA certificate issued under this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A request to revoke a certificate must identify the certificate to be revoked, explain the reason for revocation, and allow the request to be authenticated (e.g., digitally or manually signed).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The steps involved in the process of requesting a certificate revocation must be detailed in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where Subscribers use hardware tokens, revocation is optional if all the following conditions are met:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the revocation request was not for key compromise;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the hardware token does not permit the Subscriber to export the signature private key;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the Subscriber surrenders the token to an authorized individual (e.g., supervisor, human resources, RA, or CA representative);

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the token was zeroized or destroyed promptly upon surrender;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - the token has been protected from malicious use between surrender and zeroization or destruction.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In all other cases, revocation of the certificates is mandatory.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Even where all the above conditions have been met, revocation of the associated certificates is recommended.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There is no grace period for revocation under this policy.

groups.title: 5.9.4 Time within which CA must Process the Revocation Request
Time within which CA must Process the Revocation Request Controls

controls.title: Time within which CA must Process the Revocation Request

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs will revoke certificates as quickly as practical upon receipt of a revocation request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Revocation requests must be processed before the next required CRL issuance as specified in Section 4.9.7, excepting those requests received within two hours of the next required CRL issuance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Revocation requests received within two hours of CRL issuance must be processed before the following CRL is published.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must maintain a continuous 24x7 ability to respond internally to high-priority problem reports, and where appropriate, forward such a complaint to law enforcement authorities, and/or revoke a certificate that is the subject of such a complaint.

groups.title: 5.9.5 Revocation Checking Requirements for Relying Parties
Revocation Checking Requirements for Relying Parties Controls

controls.title: Revocation Checking Requirements for Relying Parties

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Relying parties are expected to verify the validity of certificates as specified in \[RFC 5280\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice note: Use of revoked certificates could have damaging or catastrophic consequences. The matter of how often new revocation data should be obtained is a determination to be made by the relying party, considering the risk, responsibility, and consequences for using a certificate whose revocation status cannot be guaranteed. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CRLs must be issued periodically, even if there are no changes to be made, to ensure timeliness of information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificate status information may be issued more frequently than the issuance frequency described below.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificate status information must be published not later than the next scheduled update.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This will facilitate the local caching of certificate status information for off-line or remote operation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ||Maximum Interval for Routine CRL Issuance|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Online CA|Offline CA*|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Interval|nextUpdate|Interval|nextUpdate|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Shared Service Provider CAs |18 hours|48 hours|35 days|37 days|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |All other CAs|18 hours|180 hours|35 days|37 days|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: \*An offline CA may incorporate locally attached network equipment such as an HSM or storage array.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA system and any such locally attached network equipment must be completely isolated (air-gapped) from all other networks and computing systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: With the exception of Content Signers, offline CAs must not issue certificates to Subscribers, as defined in Section 1.3.4.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Circumstances related to emergency CRL issuance are specified in Section 4.9.12.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that operate online, CRLs must be published within 4 hours of generation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that operate offline, pre-generated CRLs intended for publication more than 4 hours after generation must be protected in the same manner as the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All pre-generated CRLs not yet published must be securely destroyed whenever the CA revokes any certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CPS must describe protections and processes used for generation and protection of any pre-generated CRLs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Furthermore, each CRL must be published no later than the time specified in the nextUpdate field of the previously issued CRL.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Note:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If pre-generation of CRLs is implemented, the thisUpdate field will be the date of generation and the nextUpdate value will be no more than 37 days beyond the date of planned publication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs must support on-line status checking via OCSP \[RFC 6960\] for Subscriber certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Since some relying parties cannot accommodate on-line communications, all CAs must support CRLs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: OCSP services must be designed and implemented so as to provide 99% availability overall and limit scheduled down-time to 0.5% annually, with resources sufficient to provide a response time of ten (10) seconds or less under normal operating conditions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificate status information distributed via OCSP must be updated and available to relying parties to meet or exceed the requirements for CRL issuance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must operate and maintain its CRL capability with resources sufficient to provide a response time of ten (10) seconds or less under normal operating conditions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: On-line revocation status checking is optional for relying parties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates where revocation status online checking is not available, CRLs must be used.

groups.title: 5.9.10 Other Forms of Revocation Advertisements Available
Other Forms of Revocation Advertisements Available Controls

controls.title: Other Forms of Revocation Advertisements Available

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CA may also use other methods to publicize the certificates it has revoked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any alternative method must meet the following requirements:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The alternative method must be described in the CA’s approved CPS;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The alternative method must provide authentication and integrity services commensurate with the assurance level of the certificate being verified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The alternative method must meet the issuance and latency requirements for CRLs stated in Sections 4.9.7 and 4.9.8.

groups.title: 5.9.11 Special Requirements Related to Key Compromise
Special Requirements Related to Key Compromise Controls

controls.title: Special Requirements Related to Key Compromise

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a CA certificate is revoked a CRL must be issued within 18 hours of notification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a CA certificate issued under id-fpki-common-high is revoked or Subscriber certificate issued under id-fpki-common-high is revoked because of compromise or suspected compromise of a private key, a CRL must be issued within six (6) hours of notification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CA certificates, suspension is not permitted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs may support certificate suspension and restoration for Subscriber certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If suspension and restoration are supported by the CA, the CPS must describe under what circumstances and details for the corresponding sections below.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that support suspension, those authorized to request suspension of a certificate must be identified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that support suspension, all suspended certificate serial numbers must be populated on a full CRL within a timeframe specified in Section 4.9.7.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The reason code CRL entry extension shall be populated with “certificateHold.”

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that support suspension, a request to suspend a certificate must include:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - authentication of the requestor,

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - identification of the certificate to be suspended, and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - explanation of the reason for suspension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that support suspension, the maximum time period a certificate may be suspended must be specified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CPS must describe in detail how this maximum suspension period is enforced.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the subscriber has not removed the certificate from hold (suspension) within that period, the certificate must be revoked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates must not be published on a CRL with a reason code of “certificateHold” beyond the expiration date of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: In order to mitigate the threat of unauthorized person removing the certificate from hold, the identity of the RA or authorized individual removing the suspension should be authenticated using a mechanism equivalent or higher than the assurance level of the certificate being unsuspended. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 4.9.9 for OCSP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If additional certificate status services are supported, they must be described in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where applicable this must be described in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where applicable this must be described in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where applicable this must be described in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation.

groups.title: 5.12.0 Key Escrow and Recovery Policy and Practices
Key Escrow and Recovery Policy and Practices Controls

controls.title: Key Escrow and Recovery Policy and Practices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA private keys are never escrowed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Human Subscriber key management keys must be escrowed to provide key recovery.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Escrowed keys must be maintained within an online KED for a minimum of one year after the expiration of the associated public key certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber signature keys are never escrowed.

groups.title: Key Escrow Process and Responsibilities Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Human subscriber private keys (i.e., decryption private keys) associated with a key management certificate must be securely escrowed by the KED.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must ensure that the keys are escrowed successfully prior to issuance of the key management certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber private keys must be protected during transit and storage using cryptography at least as strong as the key being escrowed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers must be notified that the private keys associated with their encryption certificates will be escrowed.

groups.title: Key Recovery Process and Responsibilities Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Communications between the various key recovery participants (KED, DDS, KRA, KRO, Requestor, and Subscriber) must be secured from protocol threats such as disclosure, modification, replay, and substitution.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The strength of all cryptographic protocols must be equal to or greater than that of the keys they protect.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: During delivery, escrowed keys must be protected against disclosure to any party except the Requestor.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When any mechanism that includes a shared secret (e.g., a password) is used to protect the key in transit, the mechanism must ensure that the Requestor and the transmitting party are the only holders of this shared secret.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers may use electronic or manual means to request their own escrowed keys from the KRS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Subscriber may submit the request to the KED, KRA or KRO.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the request is made electronically, the subscriber must digitally sign the request or authenticate to a recovery service using an associated authentication or signature certificate with an assurance level equal to or greater than that of the escrowed key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Manual requests must be made in person, and include proper identity verification by the KRA in accordance with Section 3.2.3.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Third-Party Requestors may use electronic or manual means to request the Subscribers’ escrowed keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Requestor must submit the request to the KRA or KRO.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the request is made electronically, the Requestor must digitally sign the request using a trusted authentication or signature certificate, as determined by the recovering organization, with an assurance level equal to or greater than that of the escrowed key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Manual requests must include proper identity verification by the KRA in accordance with Section 3.2.3.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DDSs must use electronic means to request Subscribers’ escrowed keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requests must be authenticated as specified in Section 3.5.5.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Third party key recovery in and of itself does not require revocation of a subscriber certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This does not prohibit Subscribers from revoking their own certificates for any reason.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRA must provide access to a copy of an escrowed key only in response to a properly authenticated and authorized key recovery request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Such access requires the actions of at least two KRAs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All copies of escrowed keys must be protected using two-person control procedures during recovery and delivery to the authenticated and authorized Requestor.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Split key or password procedures are considered adequate two-person controls, provided they comply with technical controls in Section 6.2.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: A combination of physical, procedural and technical security controls can be used to enforce continuous two-person control during recovery and delivery of escrowed keys. The KRS should be designed to maximize the ability to enforce two-person control technically. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRA is not required to notify subscribers of a third-party key recovery.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A current Subscriber’s escrowed keys may be provided directly to the Subscriber without imposition of two-person control requirements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KED must only provide escrowed keys to current Subscribers without two-person control upon:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verifying that the authenticated identity of the Requestor is the same as the Subscriber associated with the escrowed keys being requested;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Sending notification to the Subscriber of all attempts (successful or unsuccessful) to recover the Subscriber’s escrowed keys that are made by entities claiming to be the subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the KED does not have information (e.g., an e-mail address) necessary to send notification to the Subscriber of a key recovery request, then the KED must not provide the Subscriber with the requested key material using the automated recovery process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: Where possible, the e-mail address will be from the subject alternative name field of the certificate being recovered. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensuring that the escrowed keys are being sent only to the authenticated Subscriber associated with the escrowed keys; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensuring that the escrowed keys are encrypted during transmission using cryptography of equal or greater strength than provided by the escrowed keys.

groups.title: Key Recovery During Token Issuance Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a Subscriber (individual and/or group/role sponsor or member) is issued a new certificate on a hardware token, private key management keys for the Subscriber may be recovered as part of the issuance process as long as the KED uses secure means, such as Global Platform Secure Channel Protocol, to inject the key history onto the hardware token directly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The hardware token must meet FIPS 140 Level 2 hardware requirements and the key must be injected into the token such that it is not thereafter exportable.

groups.title: 5.12.1.5 Key Recovery by Data Decryption Server
Key Recovery by Data Decryption Server Controls

controls.title: Key Recovery by Data Decryption Server

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A DDS must be under two-person control, as is required for any CA or KED.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A DDS is permitted to automatically recover keys from the KED.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KED must perform the following activities prior to releasing the key:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Authenticating the Requestor as a legitimate DDS;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verifying that the DDS is authorized to recover the escrowed key for the Issuing Organization to which the key belongs;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensuring that the escrowed keys are protected during transmission using cryptography or other means of equal or greater strength than provided by the escrowed keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In order to prevent any individual KRA, KRO or another trusted role from accessing subscriber encryption keys, a combination of physical, procedural and technical security controls must be used to enforce continuous two-person control on the DDSs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The DDSs must be designed to maximize the ability to enforce two-person control technically.

groups.title: 5.12.1.6 Who Can Submit a Key Recovery Application
Who Can Submit a Key Recovery Application Controls

controls.title: Who Can Submit a Key Recovery Application

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers may request recovery of their own escrowed keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Key recovery may also be requested by internal Third-Party Requestor permitted by the Issuing Organization policy, as verified by the KRO, and by authorized external Third-Party Requestors (e.g., law enforcement personnel with a court order from a competent court).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRA or the KRO, as an intermediary for the KRA, must validate the authorization of the Requestor in consultation with Issuing Organization management and/or legal counsel, as appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Issuing Organizations must determine internal notification requirements for External Third-Party key recovery requests and account for situations where the law requires the KED to release the Subscriber’s private key without organizational notification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Nothing in this document is intended to change the current procedures for obtaining information about individuals in connection with such requests.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Current Subscribers are authorized to recover their own escrowed key material.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KED must verify that the KRA has appropriate privileges to obtain the keys for the identified Subscriber’s organization.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KED or KRA must verify that the KRO is authorized to request keys for the identified Subscriber.

groups.title: Data Decryption Server Authorization Validation Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KED must verify that the DDS recovery request falls within the organizational scope for which the DDS was established.

groups.title: 5.12.1 Session Key Encapsulation and Recovery Policy and Practices
Session Key Encapsulation and Recovery Policy and Practices Controls

controls.title: Session Key Encapsulation and Recovery Policy and Practices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that support session key encapsulation and recovery must identify the document describing the practices in the applicable CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA equipment must be protected from unauthorized access while the cryptographic module is installed and activated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must implement physical access controls to reduce the risk of equipment tampering even when the cryptographic module is not installed and activated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA cryptographic tokens must be protected against theft, loss, and unauthorized use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All the physical control requirements specified below apply equally to all CAs, and any remote workstations used to administer the CAs except where specifically noted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The location and construction of the facility housing the CA equipment, as well as sites housing remote workstations used to administer the CAs, must be consistent with facilities used to house high-value, sensitive information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The site location and construction, when combined with other physical security protection mechanisms such as guards, high security locks, and intrusion sensors, must provide robust protection against unauthorized access to the CA equipment and records.

groups.title: Physical Access for CA Equipment Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, the physical access controls for CA equipment, as well as remote workstations used to administer the CAs, must:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensure that no unauthorized access to the hardware is permitted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensure that all removable media and paper containing sensitive plain-text information is stored in secure containers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Be manually or electronically monitored for unauthorized intrusion at all times.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Ensure an access log is maintained and inspected periodically.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Require two-person physical access control to both the cryptographic module and computer systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When not in use, removable cryptographic modules, activation information used to access or enable cryptographic modules, and CA equipment must be placed in secure containers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Activation data must be either memorized or recorded and stored in a manner commensurate with the security afforded the cryptographic module, and must not be stored with the cryptographic module or removable hardware associated with remote workstations used to administer the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A security check of the facility housing the CA equipment or remote workstations used to administer the CAs must occur if the facility is to be left unattended.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, the check must verify the following:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The equipment is in a state appropriate to the current mode of operation (e.g., that cryptographic modules are in place when “open,” and secured when “closed,” and for the CA, that all equipment other than the repository is shut down).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any security containers are properly secured.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Physical security systems (e.g., door locks, vent covers) are functioning properly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The area is secured against unauthorized access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A person or group of persons must be made explicitly responsible for making such checks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a group of persons is responsible, a log identifying the person performing a check at each instance must be maintained.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the facility is not continuously attended, the last person to depart must initial a sign-out sheet that indicates the date and time and asserts that all necessary physical protection mechanisms are in place and activated.

groups.title: Physical Access for RA Equipment Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RA equipment must be protected from unauthorized access while the cryptographic module is installed and activated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The RA must implement physical access controls to reduce the risk of equipment tampering even when the cryptographic module is not installed and activated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These security mechanisms must be commensurate with the level of threat in the RA equipment environment.

groups.title: Physical Access for CSS Equipment Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Physical access control requirements for CSS equipment that has signing capability must meet the CA physical access requirements specified in Section 5.1.2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CSS equipment that do not have a private signing key and only distribute pre-generated OCSP responses are not required to meet these requirements.

groups.title: Physical Access for KED Equipment Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Physical access control requirements for KED equipment that store private keys must meet the CA physical access requirements specified in Section 5.1.2.1.

groups.title: Physical Access for DDS Equipment Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Physical access control requirements for DDS equipment that store or use private keys must meet the CA physical access requirements specified in Section 5.1.2.1.

groups.title: 6.1.2.5 Physical Access for KRA and KRO Equipment
Physical Access for KRA and KRO Equipment Controls

controls.title: Physical Access for KRA and KRO Equipment

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: KRA and KRO equipment must be protected from unauthorized access while the cryptographic module is installed and activated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The KRA and KRO must implement physical access controls to reduce the risk of equipment tampering even when the cryptographic module is not installed and activated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These security mechanisms must be commensurate with the level of threat in the equipment environment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must have sufficient alternative power supply in the event of a primary power source failure to either maintain CA operations or, at a minimum, prevent loss of data.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The repositories (containing CA certificates, CRLs, and pre-generated OCSP responses) must be provided with uninterrupted power sufficient for a minimum of six (6) hours operation in the absence of commercial power, to maintain availability and avoid denial of service.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA equipment must be installed such that it is not in danger of exposure to water (e.g., on tables or elevated floors).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Potential water damage from fire prevention and protection measures (e.g., sprinkler systems) are excluded from this requirement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must comply with local commercial building codes for fire prevention and protection.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media must be stored so as to protect them from accidental damage (e.g., water, fire, or electromagnetic) and unauthorized physical access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Sensitive media and documentation that are no longer needed for operations must be destroyed in a secure manner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For example, sensitive paper documentation must be shredded, burned, or otherwise rendered unrecoverable.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA backups sufficient to recover from system failure must be made on a periodic schedule, and described in a CA’s CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backups are to be performed and stored off-site not less than once per week.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At least one full backup copy must be stored at an off-site location (separate from CA equipment).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only the latest full backup need be retained.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The backup must be stored at a site with physical and procedural controls commensurate to that of the operational CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For offline CAs, the backup must be performed each time the system is turned on or once per week, whichever is less frequent.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requirements for CA private key backup are specified in Section 6.2.4.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Trusted Role is one whose incumbent performs functions that can introduce security problems if not carried out properly, whether accidentally or maliciously.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The personnel selected to fill these roles must be extraordinarily responsible, or the integrity of the CA will be weakened.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The functions performed in these roles form the basis of trust for the entire PKI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Two approaches are taken to increase the likelihood that these roles can be successfully carried out.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The first ensures that the person filling the role is trustworthy and properly trained.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The second distributes the functions among more than one person, so that any malicious activity would require collusion.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements of this policy are defined in terms of four roles, implementing organizations may define additional roles provided the following separation of duties are enforced.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  Administrator – authorized to install, configure, and maintain the CA, KED or DDS; establish and maintain system accounts; configure audit parameters; and generate PKI component keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  Officer – authorized to request or approve certificate issuance, revocations, or recovery, as appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  Auditor – authorized to review, maintain, and archive audit logs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 4.  Operator – authorized to perform system backup and recovery.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Administrators do not issue certificates to Subscribers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These four roles are employed at the CA, RA, KED, DDS and CSS locations as appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Separation of duties must comply with Section 5.2.4, and requirements for two-person control with Section 5.2.2, regardless of the titles and numbers of Trusted Roles.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All KRAs that operate under this policy are subject to the stipulations of this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A KRA’s responsibilities are to ensure that the following functions occur according to the stipulations of this policy:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Authorized to authenticate requests and recover copies of escrowed keys; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Authorized to distribute copies of recovered keys to Requestor, with protection as described in Section 4.12.1.2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: KROs are defined as Trusted Roles only if they have privileged access to the KED.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A KRO’s responsibilities are to ensure that the following functions occur according to the stipulations of this policy:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Authorized to verify a Requestor’s identity and authorization as stated by this policy;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Authorized to build key recovery requests on behalf of authorized Requestor;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Authorized to securely communicate key recovery requests to and responses from the KRA; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Authorized to participate in distribution of escrowed keys to the Requestor, as described by the associated practice statement (CPS or KRPS).

groups.title: 6.2.1 Number of Persons Required per Task
Number of Persons Required per Task Controls

controls.title: Number of Persons Required per Task

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Two or more persons are required for the following tasks:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA, KED, or DDS key generation;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA signing key activation;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA, KED, or DDS private key backup.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where multiparty control is required, at least one of the participants must be an Administrator.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All participants must serve in a Trusted Role as defined in Section 5.2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multiparty control must not be achieved using personnel that serve in the Auditor Trusted Role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The participation of two KRAs is required for third-party key recovery.

groups.title: 6.2.2 Identification and Authentication for Each Role
Identification and Authentication for Each Role Controls

controls.title: Identification and Authentication for Each Role

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An individual must identify and authenticate him/herself before being permitted to perform any actions set forth above for that role or identity.

groups.title: Roles Requiring Separation of Duties Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Individuals may only assume one of the Officer, Administrator, and Auditor roles, but any individual may assume the Operator role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA and RA software and hardware must identify and authenticate its users and must ensure that no user identity can assume both the Administrator and Officer roles, assume both the Administrator and Auditor roles, or assume both the Auditor and Officer roles.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that issue at id-fpki-common-high, the Auditor may not assume any other role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No individual must have more than one identity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Trusted Role may perform the same role on the CA, KED, and DDS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Under no circumstances will a KRA or KRO be an Administrator or Auditor for a KED or DDS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Registration Authority (RA) may fill the role of a KRA or KRO.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Trusted Agent (TA), may fill the role of a KRO.

groups.title: Qualifications, Experience, and Clearance Requirements Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All persons filling Trusted Roles must be selected on the basis of loyalty, trustworthiness, and integrity, and must be U.S. citizens.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirements governing the qualifications, selection and oversight of individuals who operate, manage, oversee, and audit the CA must be set forth in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIMA Program Manager must hold a Top Secret security clearance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Trusted Roles must receive a favorable adjudication after undergoing a background investigation covering the following areas:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Employment;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Education;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Place of residence;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Law Enforcement; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - References.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The period of investigation must cover at least the last five years for each area, excepting the residence check which must cover at least the last three years.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Regardless of the date of award, the highest educational degree must be verified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Adjudication of the background investigation must be performed by a competent adjudication authority using a process consistent with \[Executive Order 12968\], or equivalent.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All personnel performing duties with respect to the operation of the CA or RA must receive comprehensive training.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Training must be conducted in the following areas:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA (or RA) security principles and mechanisms;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All PKI software versions in use on the CA (or RA) system;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All PKI duties they are expected to perform;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Disaster recovery and business continuity procedures; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Stipulations of this policy and appropriate CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All individuals responsible for PKI roles must be made aware of changes in the CA operation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any significant change to the operations must have a training (awareness) plan, and the execution of such plan must be documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Examples of such changes are CA software or hardware upgrade, changes in automated security systems, and relocation of equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Documentation must be maintained identifying all personnel who received training and the level of training completed.

groups.title: Job Rotation Frequency and Sequence Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Job rotation must not violate role separation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All access rights associated with a previous role must be terminated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All job rotations must be documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Individuals assuming an auditor role must not audit their own work from a previous role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must take appropriate administrative and disciplinary actions against personnel who have performed actions involving the CA or its RAs that are not authorized in this CP, CPSs, or other published procedures.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Contractors fulfilling Trusted Roles are subject to all personnel requirements stipulated in this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PKI vendors who provide any services must establish procedures to ensure that any subcontractors perform in accordance with this policy and the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Documentation sufficient to define duties and procedures for each role must be provided to the personnel filling that role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The objective of audit log processing is to review all actions to ensure they are made by authorized parties and for legitimate reasons.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, audit records must be generated for all events identified in Section 5.4.1 of this policy, and must be available during audit reviews and third-party audits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs operated in a virtual environment, audit records must be generated for all applicable events on application software and all system software layers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where possible, the audit records must be automatically collected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where this is not possible, a logbook, paper form, other physical or electronic mechanism must be used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Audit record reviews should be performed using an automated process, and must include verification that the logs have not been tampered with, an inspection of log entries, and a root cause analysis for any alerts or irregularities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Implementation and documentation of automated tools must meet the requirements of the CP such that relevant events and anomalies are identified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Reviews may be performed manually for physical or non-electronic records and logs, or when the audit log is small enough to allow for a thorough manual review.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All anomalous events must be analyzed to determine the cause and to ensure that the system is operating correctly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A record of the review, all significant events, and any actions taken as a result of these reviews must be explained in an audit log summary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This review summary must be retained as part of the long-term archive.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All KED audit records of unsuccessful key recoveries must be analyzed to determine the cause and to ensure that the KRS is operating correctly and securely, and is not vulnerable to unauthorized use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All security auditing capabilities of CA operating system and CA applications required by this CP (including the KRS) must be enabled during installation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, each audit record must include the following (either recorded automatically or manually for each auditable event):

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - What type of event occurred;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Date and time when the event occurred;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Where the event occurred (e.g., on what systems or in what physical locations);

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Source of the event;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Outcome of the event to include success or failure; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Identity of any individuals, subjects, or objects/entities associated with the event

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any request or action requiring the use of a private key controlled by the CA is an auditable event.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If out-of-band processes are used for authorization of certificate issuance, external artifacts from the process (e.g., forms, emails, etc.) must be recorded.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: Events related to CA certificate issuance may be different from those related to subscriber certificate issuance |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA and KRS must record all events identified in the list below, where applicable to the application, environment, or both.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where these events cannot be electronically logged, electronic audit logs must be supplemented with physical logs as necessary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - SECURITY AUDIT:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any changes to the Audit parameters, e.g., audit frequency, type of event audited

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any attempt to delete or modify the Audit logs

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - IDENTIFICATION AND AUTHENTICATION:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Platform or CA application level authentication attempts

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The value of maximum authentication attempts is changed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Maximum authentication attempts unsuccessful authentication attempts occur during user login

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - An Administrator unlocks an account that has been locked as a result of unsuccessful authentication attempts

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - An Administrator changes the type of authenticator, e.g., from smart card login to password

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - DATA ENTRY AND OUTPUT:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any additional event that is relevant to the security of the CA (such as remote or local data entry or data export); must be documented

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - KEY GENERATION:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Whenever the CA generates a key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (Not mandatory for single session or one-time use symmetric keys)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - PRIVATE KEY LOAD AND STORAGE:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The loading of CA, RA, CSS, CMS, or other keys used by the CA in the lifecycle management of certificates

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All access to certificate subject private keys retained within the CA for key recovery purposes

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - TRUSTED PUBLIC KEY ENTRY, DELETION AND STORAGE:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any changes to public keys used by components of the CA to authenticate other components or authorize certificate lifecycle requests (e.g., RA or CMS trust stores)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - PRIVATE AND SECRET KEY EXPORT:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The export of private and secret keys (keys used for a single session or message are excluded)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CERTIFICATE REGISTRATION:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All records related to certificate request authorization, approval and signature, whether generated directly on the CA or generated by a related external system or process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CERTIFICATE REVOCATION:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All records related to certificate revocation request authorization, approval and execution, whether generated directly on the CA or generated by a related external system or process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CERTIFICATE STATUS CHANGE APPROVAL:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All records related to certificate status change request authorization, approval and execution, whether generated directly on the CA or generated by a related external system or process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA CONFIGURATION:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any security-relevant changes to the configuration of the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The specific configuration items relevant to the environment in which the CA operates must be identified and documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - ACCOUNT ADMINISTRATION:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Roles and users are added or deleted

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The access control privileges of a user account or a role are modified

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CERTIFICATE PROFILE MANAGEMENT:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All changes to the certificate profile

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CERTIFICATE REVOCATION LIST PROFILE MANAGEMENT:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All changes to the certificate revocation list profile

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - MISCELLANEOUS:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Appointment of an individual to a designated trusted role

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: If multiparty control is implemented via team separation, these records must include team appointment specifics. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Installation of the operating system

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Installation of the CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Installing hardware cryptographic modules

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Removing hardware cryptographic modules

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Destruction of cryptographic modules

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - System startup

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Logon attempts to CA applications

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Receipt of hardware / software

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Attempts to set passwords

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Attempts to modify passwords

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Backing up CA internal database

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Restoring CA internal database

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Records of manipulation of critical files (e.g. creation, renaming, moving), critical files will vary between installation, and must be identified in the relevant documentation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Posting of any material to a repository

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The date and time any CA artifact is posted to a public repository

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Access to CA internal database

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All certificate compromise notification requests

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Loading tokens with certificates

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Shipment and receipt of tokens containing key material, or tokens that allow access to key material (e.g., HSM operator cards)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Zeroizing tokens

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Re-key of the CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Configuration changes to the CA server involving:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Hardware

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Software

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Operating system

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Patches

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Security profiles

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - PHYSICAL ACCESS / SITE SECURITY:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Personnel access to room housing CA

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Access to the CA server

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Known or suspected violations of physical security

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - ANOMALIES:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Software error conditions

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Software check integrity failures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Equipment failure

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Electrical power outages

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Uninterruptible power supply (UPS) failure

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Network service or access failures that could affect certificate trust

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Violations of certificate policy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Violations of certification practice statement

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Resetting operating system clock

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Audit records must be reviewed at least once every month for CAs that issue certificates under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CSS, CMS, IDMS and KRS audit log processing frequency shall align with the CA audit log processing frequency described above.

groups.title: Retention Period for Audit Log Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Audit records must be accessible until reviewed, in addition to specific records being archived as described in Section 5.5.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System configuration and operational procedures must be implemented together to ensure that only authorized individuals may move or archive audit records and that audit records are not modified before review.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Collection of the audit records from the CA system must be performed by, witnessed by or under the control of trusted roles who are different from the individuals who, in combination, command the CA signature key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For RA systems, the individual authorized to move or archive records may not hold an RA Trusted Role.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Procedures must be implemented to protect audit records from deletion or destruction before they are reviewed as described in Section 5.4.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: To protect the integrity of audit records, they must be transferred to a backup environment distinct from the environment where the audit records are generated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Audit records and audit summaries must be backed up at least monthly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If audit records are stored locally in the system where the events occur, they must be transferred to a backup environment and protected as described in Section 5.4.4.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The backup procedure may be automated or manual, but must occur no less frequently than the audit log review described in Section 5.4.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The process for transferring the audit records to the backup environment must be documented.

groups.title: Audit Collection System (Internal vs. External) Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The audit log collection system may or may not be external to the CA system or KRS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Automated audit processes must be invoked at system or application startup, and cease only at system or application shutdown.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Audit collection systems must be configured such that security audit data is protected against loss (e.g., overwriting or overflow of automated log files).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If an automated audit system has failed, and the integrity of the system or confidentiality of the information protected by the system is at risk, operations must be suspended until the problem has been remedied.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There is no requirement to notify a subject that an event was audited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Real-time alerts are neither required nor prohibited by this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs must perform routine vulnerability assessments of the security controls described in this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Self-assessment of controls and control effectiveness (e.g., FISMA) must be performed in accordance with the frequency determined by the risk rating of the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Automated vulnerability scans, if executed, should be run no less frequently than required by the risk rating of the component.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The methodology, tools and frequency of the vulnerability assessment must be documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: The audit data should be reviewed by the auditor for events such as repeated failed actions, requests for privileged information, attempted access of system files, requests for escrowed keys, attempted access of escrowed keys, unauthenticated responses, and other suspicious or unusual activity. Auditors should check for continuity of the audit data. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The primary objective of the CA archive is to prove the validity of any certificate (including those revoked or expired) issued by the CA in the event of dispute regarding the use of the certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The primary objective of the KRS archive is reconstruction of key recovery activities, in case of dispute.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Examples of disputes may include:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Validation of key recovery requests

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Validation of the identity of the recipient of an escrowed key;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verification of authorization to obtain the escrowed key copy;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Verification of transfer of custody of escrowed keys to an authorized Requestor; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Establishment of the circumstances under which a copy of the escrowed key was provided.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA archive records must be sufficiently detailed to determine the proper operation of the CA and the validity of any certificate (including those revoked or expired) issued by the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At a minimum, the following data must be recorded for archive:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificate Policy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certification Practice Statement / Key Recovery Practice Statement

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Contractual obligations and other agreements concerning operations of the CA or KRS

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - System and equipment configuration

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Modifications and updates to system or configuration

parts.name: statement
