parts.prose: - All records related to certificate request authorization, approval and signature, whether generated directly on the CA or generated as part of a related external system or process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All certificates issued and/or published

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Record of re-key

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All records related to certificate revocation, whether generated directly on the CA or generated as part of a related external system or process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Subscriber identity authentication data as per Section 3.2.3

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Documentation of receipt and acceptance of certificates

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Subscriber agreements

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Documentation of receipt of tokens

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Other data or applications to verify archive contents (e.g., key escrow software)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Audit summary reports generated by internal reviews and documentation generated during third party audits

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any changes to the Audit parameters, e.g., audit frequency, type of event audited

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Any attempt to delete or modify the Audit logs

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Whenever the CA generates a key (not mandatory for single session or one-time use symmetric keys)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All access to certificate subject private keys retained within the CA for key recovery purposes

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Changes to trusted public keys used or published by the CA including certificates used for trust between the CA and other components such as CMS, RA, etc.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The export of private and secret keys (keys used for a single session or message are excluded)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The approval or rejection of a certificate status change request

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Appointment of an individual to a Trusted Role (to include KRA/KRO)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Destruction of cryptographic modules

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - All certificate compromise notifications

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Remedial action taken as a result of violations of physical security

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Violations of Certificate Policy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Violations of Certification Practice Statement / Key Recovery Practice Statement

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Archive retention periods begin at the key generation event for any CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs that leverage key-rollover procedures a new retention period begins for each subsequent key generation event.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs will maintain all archived records related to that CA, in an accessible fashion, for 3 years after CA expiration or CA termination.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Individual records associated with certificate request authorization, certificate revocation, subscriber authentication, or subscriber certificate acceptance must be maintained for a minimum of 3 years after the subject certificate expiration date.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Issuance of new certificates with extended validity periods (i.e., renewal, rekey or modification) supported by existing subscriber authentication records (i.e., authentication using an existing valid certificate) will result in a new retention period for those initial records, based on the new certificate expiration date.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | **Practice Note**: Archive records can be retained for as long as business purposes require; however, this policy does not waive any organizational policies that may require the destruction of such records or otherwise limits their retention periods. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | **Practice Note**: If the archive records are maintained separately from the CA, communication processes may be required to determine when archive records are no longer needed based on related public certificates. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: National Archives and Records Administration General Records Schedules \[NARA GRS\], 5.6 Item 120, defines other required RA chain-of-trust records, and archive retention periods related to credentials issued in support of HSPD-12.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RA system operations audit records that include any IT resources that facilitate RA functions, must maintain relevant archives for a minimum of 3 years after RA system replacement or termination

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only Auditors, as described in Section 5.2, or other personnel specifically authorized by the CA are permitted to add or delete records from the archive.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Deletion of records identified in Section 5.5.1 before the end of the retention period is not permitted under any circumstances.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The contents of the archive must not be released except in accordance with Sections 9.3 and 9.4, or under circumstances described in the approved CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Archive media must be stored in a safe, secure storage facility geographically separate from the CA using procedures approved by NARA or according to agency-specific policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The transfer process between the backup environment and archive location must be documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In order to ensure that records in the archive may be referenced when required, the CA must do one of the following:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Maintain the hardware or software required to process or read the archive records, or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Define a process to transfer records to a new format or medium when the old format or medium becomes obsolete and verify the integrity of the records after transfer

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation.

groups.title: Requirements for Time-Stamping of Records Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA archive records must have accurate time-stamps when they are added to the archive.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The time precision must be such that the sequence of events can be determined.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CPS or KRPS must describe how system clocks used for time-stamping are maintained in synchrony with an authoritative time standard.

groups.title: Archive Collection System (Internal or External) Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Archive data may be collected in any expedient manner, but must be documented in the associated CPS/KRPS.

groups.title: 6.5.6 Procedures to Obtain and Verify Archive Information
Procedures to Obtain and Verify Archive Information Controls

controls.title: Procedures to Obtain and Verify Archive Information

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Copies of records of individual transactions may be released upon request of any Subscribers involved in the transaction or their legally recognized agents.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Procedures, detailing how to create, verify, package, transmit, and store the CA/KRS archive information, must be included in the CPS/KRPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each CA’s signing key must have a validity period as described in Section 6.3.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Prior to the end of a CA’s signing key validity period, a new CA must be established or a re-key on the existing CA must be performed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This is referred to as key changeover.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: From that time on, only the new key must be used to sign CA and Subscriber certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The old private key may continue to be used to sign CRLs and OCSP responder certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the old private key is used to sign OCSP responder certificates or CRLs that cover certificates signed with that key, the old key must be retained and protected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: After all certificates signed with the old key have expired or been revoked, the CA may issue a final long-term CRL using the old key, with a nextUpdate time past the validity period of all issued certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This final CRL must be available for all relying parties until the validity period of all issued certificates has passed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once the last CRL has been issued, the old private signing key of the CA may be destroyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a CA performs a key changeover and thus generates a new public key, the CA must notify all CAs, RAs, and Subscribers that rely on the CA’s certificate that it has been changed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a CA performs a key changeover, the CA may generate key rollover certificates, where the new public key is signed by the old private key, and vice versa.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This permits immediate acceptance of newly issued certificates and CRLs by current users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs under this policy must have an incident handling process, which documents any security incidents.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security incidents may include violation or threat of violation to the system, improper usage, malicious or anomalous activity and violations of the CPS or CP.

groups.title: Incident and Compromise Handling Procedures Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA must be notified within 24 hours if any CAs operating under this policy experience the following:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - suspected or detected compromise of the CA systems;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - physical or electronic penetration of CA systems;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - successful denial of service attacks on CA components;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - any incident preventing the CA from issuing a CRL prior to the nextUpdate time of the previous CRL;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - suspected or detected compromise of a CSS; or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - suspected or detected compromise of an RA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The notification must include preliminary remediation analysis.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once the incident has been resolved, the organization operating the CA must provide notification directly to the FPKIPA which includes detailed measures taken to remediate the incident.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The notice must include the following:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 1.  Which CA components were affected by the incident

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 2.  The CA's interpretation of the incident

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3.  Who is impacted by the incident

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 4.  When the incident was discovered

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 5.  A complete list of all certificates that may have been issued erroneously or are not compliant with the CP/CPS as a result of the incident

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 6.  A statement that the incident has been fully remediated

groups.title: 6.7.1 Computing Resources, Software, and/or Data Are Corrupted
Computing Resources, Software, and/or Data Are Corrupted Controls

controls.title: Computing Resources, Software, and/or Data Are Corrupted

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When computing resources, software, and/or data are corrupted, CAs must respond as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Before returning to operation, ensure that the system’s integrity has been restored.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - If the CA signature keys are not destroyed, CA operation must be reestablished, giving priority to the ability to generate certificate status information within the CRL issuance schedule specified in Section 4.9.7.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - If the CA signature keys are destroyed, CA operation must be reestablished as quickly as possible, giving priority to the generation of a new CA key pair.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The customer Agency Points of Contact (POC) must be notified as soon as possible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event of an incident as described above, the organization operating the CA must post a notice on its web page identifying the incident and provide notification to the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 5.7.1 for contents of the notice.

groups.title: CA Private Key Compromise Procedures Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event of a CA private key compromise, the following operations must be performed:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The CA must immediately inform the FPKIPA and any entities known to be distributing the CA certificate (e.g., in a root store).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The CA must request revocation of any certificates issued to the compromised CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The CA must generate new keys in accordance with Section 6.1.1.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the CA distributed the public key in a Trusted Certificate, the CA must perform the following operations:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Generate a new Trusted Certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Securely distribute the new Trusted Certificate as specified in Section 6.1.4.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Initiate procedures to notify Subscribers of the compromise.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber certificates issued prior to compromise of the CA private key may be renewed automatically by the CA under the new key pair (see Section 4.6) or the CA may require Subscribers to repeat the initial certificate application process.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organization operating the CA must post a notice on its web page describing the compromise.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 5.7.1 for contents of the notice.

groups.title: KRS Private Key Compromise Procedures Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event that the KED or DDS is compromised or is suspected to be compromised, the following operations must be performed:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Notify the FPKIPA of the compromise

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Provide detail concerning the root cause, operational impact and initial remediation actions

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Determine the extent of the compromise

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Gain concurrence from the FPKIPA on planned resolution.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This may include revocation of certificates associated with the compromised private keys stored in the KED or DDS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If a KRA or KRO certificate is revoked due to compromise, the potential exists for some Subscribers’ escrowed keys to have been exposed during a recovery process, the following operations must be performed:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Audit record review by the audit administrator to identify all potentially exposed escrowed keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Revocation of each of the potentially exposed escrowed keys, according to procedures specified in Section 4.9.3, to include Subscriber notification of the revocation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Reissuance of the KRA or KRO authentication certificate

groups.title: 6.7.3 Business Continuity Capabilities after a Disaster
Business Continuity Capabilities after a Disaster Controls

controls.title: Business Continuity Capabilities after a Disaster

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For the Federal Common Policy CA, recovery procedures must be in place to reconstitute the CA within six (6) hours of failure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All other CAs operating under this policy must have recovery procedures in place to reconstitute the CA within 72 hours of failure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the case of a disaster whereby the CA installation is physically damaged and all copies of the CA signature key are destroyed as a result, the FPKIPA must be notified at the earliest feasible time, and the FPKIPA must take whatever action it deems appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: KED and DDS may take more than 72 hours to restore depending on the business needs of the operator. In this event, the FPKIPA must be notified of the expected recovery timeline. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Whenever possible, the FPKIPA must be notified at least two weeks prior to the termination of a CA operating under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For emergency termination, CAs must follow the notification procedures in Section 5.7.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a CA operating under this policy terminates operations before all certificates have expired, the CA signing keys must be surrendered to the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This Section does not apply to CAs that have ceased issuing new certificates but are continuing to issue CRLs until all certificates have expired.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Such CAs are required to continue to conform with all relevant aspects of this policy (e.g., audit logging and archives).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any issued certificates that have not expired, must be revoked and a final long term CRL with a nextUpdate time past the validity period of all issued certificates must be generated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This final CRL must be available for all relying parties until the validity period of all issued certificates has passed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once the last CRL has been issued, the private signing key(s) of the CA to be terminated will be destroyed or taken offline, designated as “not in use”, and protected as stipulated in Section 5.1.2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Prior to CA/KRS termination, the CA/KRS must provide archived data to an archive facility as specified in the CPS/KRPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: As soon as possible, the CA will advise all other organizations to which it has issued certificates of its termination, using an agreed-upon method of communication specified in the CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When an organizational RA function operating under this policy terminates operations, the RA must archive all audit logs and other records prior to termination and destroy its private keys upon termination.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Key generation must be performed using a FIPS approved method or equivalent international standard.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Key generation events should use the configuration that was the basis of the FIPS or other approved standard (e.g., FIPS mode).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the required keys cannot be generated while in an approved configuration, the specific configuration and reason for use of a different method should be documented by the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic keying material used by CAs to sign certificates, CRLs or status information must be generated in \[FIPS 140\] validated cryptographic modules as specified in Section 6.2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multiparty control is required for CA key pair generation, as specified in Section 6.2.2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA key pair generation must create a verifiable audit trail that the security requirements for procedures were followed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The documentation of the procedure must be detailed enough to show that appropriate role separation was used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An independent third party must validate the execution of the key generation procedures either by witnessing the key generation or by examining the signed and documented record of the key generation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: If the audit trail identifies and documents any failures or anomalies in the key generation process, along with the corrective action taken, the key generation process need not be restarted but may continue. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber key pair generation may be performed by the Subscriber, CA, or RA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the CA or RA generates Subscriber key pairs, the requirements for key pair delivery specified in Section 6.1.2 must also be met.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber key pairs must be generated in \[FIPS 140\] validated cryptographic modules as specified in Section 6.2.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For PIV, all keys, with the exception of key management, must be generated on the card.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic keying material used by CSSs to sign status information must be generated in \[FIPS 140\] validated cryptographic modules as specified in Section 6.2.1.

groups.title: 7.1.1.3 PIV Content Signing Key Pair Generation
PIV Content Signing Key Pair Generation Controls

controls.title: PIV Content Signing Key Pair Generation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic keying material used by PIV issuing systems or devices for Common PIV Content Signing must be generated in \[FIPS 140\] validated cryptographic modules as specified in Section 6.2.1.

groups.title: Private Key Delivery to Subscriber Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If Subscribers generate their own key pairs, then there is no need to deliver private keys, and this section does not apply.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When CAs or RAs generate keys on behalf of the Subscriber, then the private key must be delivered securely to the Subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Private keys may be delivered electronically or may be delivered on a hardware cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In all cases, the following requirements must be met:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Anyone who generates a private signing key for a Subscriber must not retain any copy of the key after delivery of the private key to the Subscriber.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The private key(s) must be protected from activation, compromise, or modification during the delivery process.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The Subscriber must acknowledge receipt of the private key(s).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Delivery must be accomplished in a way that ensures that the correct tokens and activation data are provided to the correct Subscribers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - For hardware modules, accountability for the location and state of the module must be maintained until the Subscriber accepts possession of it.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - For electronic delivery of private keys, the key material must be encrypted using a cryptographic algorithm and key size at least as strong as the private key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Activation data must be delivered using a separate secure channel.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must maintain a record of the Subscriber acknowledgment of receipt of the token.

groups.title: 7.1.2 Public Key Delivery to Certificate Issuer
Public Key Delivery to Certificate Issuer Controls

controls.title: Public Key Delivery to Certificate Issuer

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where key pairs are generated by the Subscriber or RA, the public key and the Subscriber’s identity must be delivered securely to the CA for certificate issuance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The delivery mechanism must bind the Subscriber’s verified identity to the public key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If cryptography is used to achieve this binding, it must be at least as strong as the Subscriber key pair.

groups.title: 7.1.3 CA Public Key Delivery to Relying Parties
CA Public Key Delivery to Relying Parties Controls

controls.title: CA Public Key Delivery to Relying Parties

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The self-signed root CA certificates must be conveyed to relying parties in a secure fashion to preclude substitution attacks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Acceptable methods include:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Secure distribution of the certificate through secure out-of-band mechanisms;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Download the certificate from a Federal Government operated web site secured with a currently valid certificate and subsequent comparison of the hash of the certificate against a hash value made available via authenticated out-of-band sources (note that hashes posted in-band along with the certificate are not acceptable as an authentication mechanism)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: Other methods that preclude substitution attacks may be considered acceptable. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All keys must meet requirements listed in \[SP 800-57\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP requires use of RSA PKCS \#1, RSASSA-PSS, or ECDSA signatures; additional restrictions on key sizes and hash algorithms are detailed below.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under this policy must contain 2048, 3072, or 4096-bit RSA keys, or 256 or 384-bit elliptic curve keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that generate certificates and CRLs under this policy must use the SHA-256, SHA-384, or SHA-512 hash algorithm when generating digital signatures.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ||CA certificates that expire on or before December 31, 2030|CA certificates that expire after December 31, 2030 |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Minimum Key Size|RSA: 2048 Elliptic Curve: 256 |RSA: 3072 Elliptic Curve: 256 |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Hash Algorithm|SHA-256, SHA-384, or SHA-512|SHA-256, SHA-384, or SHA-512|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: KED and DDS keys must be at equal to or stronger than the keys being escrowed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ||Subscriber certificates that expire on or before December 31, 2030|Subscriber certificates that expire after December 31, 2030|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Minimum Key Size|RSA: 2048 Elliptic Curve: 256 |RSA: 3072 Elliptic Curve: 256 |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Hash Algorithm|SHA-256, SHA-384, or SHA-512|SHA-256, SHA-384, or SHA-512|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: Future versions of this policy may specify additional FIPS-approved signature algorithms. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Practice Note: Reference NIST Special Publication 800-78 for algorithms and key sizes for certificates stored on PIV or Derived PIV credentials. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Use of TLS or another protocol providing similar security to accomplish any of the requirements of this CP must require (1) AES for the symmetric key and (2) at least 2048-bit RSA or 256-bit elliptic curve keys, and at least 3072-bit RSA or at least 256-bit elliptic curve keys after December 31, 2030.

groups.title: 7.1.5 Public Key Parameters Generation and Quality Checking
Public Key Parameters Generation and Quality Checking Controls

controls.title: Public Key Parameters Generation and Quality Checking

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For RSA, the CA shall perform partial public key validation as specified in NIST SP 800-89 (Section 5.3.3).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For ECC, public keys must fall within curves defined in Section 7.1.3.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Additionally, the CA should confirm the validity of all keys using either the ECC Full Public Key Validation Routine or the ECC Partial Public Key Validation Routine as specified in NIST SP 800-56A (Sections 5.6.2.3.3, or 5.6.2.3.4).

groups.title: 7.1.6 Key Usage Purposes (as per X.509 v3 Key Usage Field)
Key Usage Purposes (as per X.509 v3 Key Usage Field) Controls

controls.title: Key Usage Purposes (as per X.509 v3 Key Usage Field)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of a specific key is constrained by the Key Usage extension in the X.509 certificate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All certificates must include a critical Key Usage extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The dataEncipherment, encipherOnly, and decipherOnly bits must not be asserted in certificates issued under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificates to be used for authentication must set only the digitalSignature bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificates to be used by Human Subscribers only for digital signatures must set the digitalSignature and nonRepudiation bits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificates that have the nonRepudiation bit set, must not have keyEncipherment bit or keyAgreement bit set.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificates to be used for encryption (RSA) must set the keyEncipherment bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Certificates to be used for key agreement (ECC) must set the keyAgreement bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - CA certificates must set only cRLSign and keyCertSign bits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Keys associated with CA certificates must be used only for signing certificates and CRLs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Keys associated with Human Subscriber certificates must be used only for digital signature (including authentication) or encryption, but not both.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates that assert id-fpki-common-authentication, id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth- hardware, id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth, id-fpki-common-cardAuth, or id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth are used solely for authentication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Keys associated with Device Subscriber certificates may be used for digital signature (including authentication), encryption, or both.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Device certificates must not assert the nonRepudiation bit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all Subscriber certificates issued after June 30, 2019, the Extended Key Usage extension must always be present.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all Subscriber certificates, Extended Key Usage OIDs must be consistent with key usage bits asserted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Extended Key Usage extension must not contain anyExtendedKeyUsage {2.5.29.37.0} or id-kpcodeSigning {1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.3}.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates that assert id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning must include a critical Extended Key Usage extension that asserts only id-PIV-content-signing {2.16.840.1.101.3.6.7} (see \[CCP-PROF\]).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates that assert id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning must include a critical Extended Key Usage extension that asserts only id-fpki-pivi-content-signing {2.16.840.1.101.3.8.7} (see \[PIV-I Profile\]).

groups.title: 7.1 Private Key Protection and Cryptographic Module Engineering Controls
Cryptographic Module Standards and Controls Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The relevant standard for cryptographic modules is Security Requirements for Cryptographic Modules \[FIPS 140\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A FIPS 140 Level 1 or higher validated cryptographic module must be used for all cryptographic operations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic modules must be minimally validated to a FIPS 140 level identified in this section.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Private Key|FIPS 140 Level|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |CA, KED, and DDS all applicable policies   |3|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |CSS all applicable policies   |2|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |PIV and Common PIV-I Content Signing id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning  id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning   |2|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Hardware Signature and Authentication id-fpki-common-authentication  id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware  id-fpki-common-cardAuth  id-fpki-common-hardware  id-fpki-common-high  id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication  id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth   |2|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Hardware Subscriber Key Management id-fpki-common-hardware   |2|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Hardware Device id-fpki-common-devicesHardware   |2|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Software Signature and Authentication id-fpki-common-policy  id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth   |1|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Software Subscriber Key Management id-fpki-common-policy   |1|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Software Device id-fpki-common-devices   |1|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RAs must use a FIPS 140 Level 2 or higher validated hardware cryptographic module when authenticating to systems to fulfill their duties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PIV or Common PIV-I cards must only be issued using card stock that has been tested and approved by the FIPS 201 Evaluation Program and listed on the GSA []

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: (http://www.idmanagement.gov/approved-products-list-apl) (APL).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Card stock that has been removed from the APL may continue to be issued for no more than one year after GSA approved replacement card stock is available.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PIV or Common PIV-I cards issued using the deprecated card stock may continue to be used until the current Subscriber certificates expire, unless otherwise notified by the FPKIPA/FPKIMA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any pseudo-random numbers used for key generation material must be generated using a FIPS-validated cryptographic module.

groups.title: 7.2.1 Private Key (n out of m) Multi-Person Control
Private Key (n out of m) Multi-Person Control Controls

controls.title: Private Key (n out of m) Multi-Person Control

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A single person must not be permitted to activate or access any cryptographic module that contains the complete CA private signing key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA signature keys may be backed up only under two-person control.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to CA signing keys backed up for disaster recovery must be under at least two-person control.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The names of the parties used for two-person control must be maintained on a list that must be made available for inspection during compliance audits.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA private keys are never escrowed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Human Subscriber key management keys must be escrowed to provide key recovery as described in Section 4.12.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If a device has a separate key management key certificate, the key management private key may be escrowed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All backups of the CA, CSS and PIV Content Signing private signature keys must be accounted for and protected under the same multi-person control as the original signature key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At least one copy of the CA private signature key must be stored off-site.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other keys, backup, when permitted, must provide security controls consistent with the protection provided by the original cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backed up private signature key(s) must not be exported or stored in plaintext form outside the cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Private Key|Backup|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |CA all applicable policies   |Required|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |CSS all applicable policies   |Optional|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |PIV and Common PIV-I Content Signing id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning  id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning   |Optional|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Hardware Signature and Authentication id-fpki-common-authentication  id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware  id-fpki-common-cardAuth  id-fpki-common-hardware  id-fpki-common-high  id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication  id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth   |Not Permitted|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Hardware Subscriber Key Management id-fpki-common-hardware   |Required|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Hardware Device id-fpki-common-devicesHardware   |Optional|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Software Signature and Authentication id-fpki-common-policy  id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth   |Optional *|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Software Subscriber Key Management id-fpki-common-policy   |Required|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Software Device id-fpki-common-devices   |Optional|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: > \* Software Subscriber private signature keys may be backed up or copied, but must be held in the Subscriber’s control.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA private signature keys and Subscriber private signature keys must not be archived.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs that retain Subscriber private encryption keys for business continuity purposes may require an archive of escrowed Subscriber private keys, so that they can be recovered for as long as the business continuity purposes require.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Archives of escrowed private keys must be protected in accordance with Sections 4.12, 5.1, 5.2, and 6.2.

groups.title: 7.2.5 Private Key Transfer into or from a Cryptographic Module
Private Key Transfer into or from a Cryptographic Module Controls

controls.title: Private Key Transfer into or from a Cryptographic Module

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At no time shall the CA private key exist in plaintext outside the cryptographic module boundary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA, CSS and PIV Content Signing private signature keys may be exported from the cryptographic module only to perform key backup procedures as described in Section 6.2.4.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In the event that any private key is transported from one cryptographic module to another, the private key must be protected using a FIPS approved algorithm and at a bit strength commensurate with the key being transported.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Private keys must never exist in plaintext form outside the cryptographic module boundary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Private or symmetric keys used to encrypt other private keys for transport must be protected from disclosure.

groups.title: 7.2.6 Private Key Storage on Cryptographic Module
Private Key Storage on Cryptographic Module Controls

controls.title: Private Key Storage on Cryptographic Module

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: No stipulation beyond that specified in \[FIPS 140\].

groups.title: Method of Activating Private Key Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic modules must be protected from unauthorized access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscriber private key activation requirements are detailed in the following table:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Policy Asserted|Activation Requirements|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |id-fpki-common-authentication id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth-hardware id-fpki-common-derived-pivAuth id-fpki-common-policy id-fpki-common-hardware id-fpki-common-high id-fpki-common-pivi-authentication |Passphrases, PINs or biometrics. When passphrases or PINs are used, they must be a minimum of six (6) characters. Entry of activation data must be protected from disclosure (i.e., the data should not be displayed while it is entered). |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |id-fpki-common-devices and id-fpki-common-devicesHardware|May be configured to activate the private key without requiring a human sponsor or authorized administrator to authenticate to the cryptographic token. The appropriate physical and logical access controls must be implemented for the device and its cryptographic token. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning |May be configured to activate the private key without requiring a human sponsor or authorized administrator to authenticate to the cryptographic token. The appropriate physical and logical access controls must be implemented for content signing operations conformant with PIV issuance requirements (see [FIPS 201]). The strength of the security controls must be commensurate with the level of threat in the PIV credential issuance system’s environment, and must protect the hardware, software, and the cryptographic token and its activation data from compromise. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |id-fpki-common-cardAuth id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth |None.|

groups.title: Method of Deactivating Private Key Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: After use, the cryptographic module must be deactivated via a manual logout procedure or automatically after a period of inactivity as defined in the applicable CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA cryptographic modules must be physically secured per requirements in Section 5.1 when not in use.

groups.title: Method of Destroying Private Key Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Individuals in Trusted Roles must destroy all copies of CA, RA, and CSS (e.g., OCSP server) private signature keys and activation data (e.g., operator card set or tokens) when they are no longer needed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Subscribers must either surrender their cryptographic module to CA/RA personnel for destruction or destroy their private signature keys, when they are no longer needed or when the certificates to which they correspond expire or are revoked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Physical destruction of hardware is not required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: Destruction will likely be performed by executing a “zeroize” command. |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: To ensure future access to encrypted data, Subscriber private key management keys should be secured in long-term backups or archived.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: See Section 6.2.1.

groups.title: 7.2 Other Aspects of Key Pair Management

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Public key archival must be in accordance with Section 5.5.

groups.title: 7.3.1 Certificate Operational Periods and Key Usage Periods
Certificate Operational Periods and Key Usage Periods Controls

controls.title: Certificate Operational Periods and Key Usage Periods

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs such as the Federal Common Policy CA that issue certificates only to other CAs or CSSs, the maximum key usage period is 20 years.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CAs operating under this policy that issue Subscriber certificates, the usage period for a CA key pair is a maximum of 10 years.[^2]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CA private key may be used to sign CRLs and OCSP responder certificates for the entire usage period.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All certificates signed by a specific CA key pair must expire before the end of that key pair’s usage period.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Key                       | Private Key  | Certificate |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Subscriber Authentication | 3 years      | 3 years     |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Subscriber Signature      | 3 years      | 3 years     |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Subscriber Encryption     | Unrestricted | 3 years     |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Card Authentication       | 3 years      | 3 years     |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Content Signing           | 3 Years      | 9 Years \*  |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | OCSP Responder            | 3 years      | 120 days    |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Device                    | 3 years      | 3 years     |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: > \* Expiration of the Content Signing certificate must be later than the expiration of the Subscriber certificates on the same PIV credential.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RA, DDS, KRA and KRO are considered Subscribers.

groups.title: Activation Data Generation and Installation Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA activation data may be user-selected (by each of the multiple parties holding that activation data).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the activation data must be transmitted, it must be via an appropriately protected channel, and distinct in time and place from the associated cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: RA and Subscriber activation data may be user-selected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The strength of the activation data must meet or exceed the requirements for authentication mechanisms stipulated for Level 2 in \[FIPS 140\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the activation data must be transmitted, it must be via an appropriately protected channel, and distinct in time and place from the associated cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data used to unlock private keys must be protected from disclosure by a combination of cryptographic and physical access control mechanisms.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Activation data must be:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - memorized;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - biometric in nature; or

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - recorded and secured at the level of assurance associated with the activation of the cryptographic module, and must not be stored with the cryptographic module.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Practice Note: Level 2 in \[FIPS 140\] requires that the protection mechanism includes a facility to protect against repeated guessing attacks. |

groups.title: Other Aspects of Activation Data Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CA operating under this policy must define any other aspects of Activation Data in its CPS.

groups.title: Specific Computer Security Technical Requirements Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For CAs, KEDs, and DDSs operating under this policy, the computer security functions listed below are required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: These functions may be provided by the operating system, or through a combination of operating system, software, and physical safeguards.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA and its ancillary parts must include the following functionality (these functions are applicable to all system software layers where applicable):

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - authenticate the identity of users before permitting access to the system, data, or applications;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - manage privileges of users to limit users to their assigned roles;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - generate and archive audit records for all transactions; (see Section 5.4)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - enforce domain integrity boundaries for security critical processes;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - require use of cryptography for session communication and database security;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - require self-test security-related CA services;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - require a trusted path for identification of all users;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - provide residual information protection; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - require recovery from key or system failure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificate status servers operating under this policy, the computer security functions listed below are required (these functions are applicable to all system software layers where applicable):

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - authenticate the identity of users before permitting access to the system or applications;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - manage privileges of users to limit users to their assigned roles;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - enforce domain integrity boundaries for security critical processes;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - provide residual information protection; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - require recovery from key or system failure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Methods used to administer the CAs, KEDs, or DDSs must not bypass applicable two-person controls.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition, the computer security functions listed below are required:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - authenticate the identity of users before permitting access to the system or applications;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - manage privileges of users to limit users to their assigned roles;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - generate and archive audit records for all transactions; (see Section 5.4)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - enforce domain integrity boundaries for security critical processes;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - prohibit object reuse or require separation for random access memory;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - provide residual information protection; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - require recovery from system failure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All communications between any PKI Trusted Role and the CA must be authenticated and protected from modification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must identify any Computer Security Rating requirements in the applicable CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The system development controls for the CA (including any remote workstations used to administer the CA) and RA are as follows:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Hardware and software used to administer or operate the CA must be procured in a fashion to reduce the likelihood that any particular component was tampered with (e.g., by ensuring the vendor cannot identify the PKI component that will be installed on a particular device).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Custom hardware and software must be developed in a controlled environment, and the development process must be defined and documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This requirement does not apply to commercial off-the-shelf hardware or software.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The CA hardware and software, including all system software layers, must be dedicated to operating and supporting the CA (i.e., the systems and services dedicated to the issuance and management of certificates).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There must be no other applications, hardware devices, network connections, or component software installed that are not parts of the CA operation, administration, monitoring and security compliance of the system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA hardware and system software layers may support multiple CAs and their supporting systems, provided all systems have comparable security controls and are dedicated to the support of the CA in compliance with this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Proper care must be taken to prevent malicious software from being loaded onto the CA equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All applications required to perform the operation of the CA must be obtained from documented sources.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: With the exception of Offline CAs, CA and RA hardware and software must be scanned for malicious code on first use and periodically thereafter.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - Hardware and software updates must be purchased or developed in the same manner as original equipment, and must be installed by trusted and trained personnel in a defined manner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The configuration of the CA system, in addition to any modifications and upgrades, must be documented and controlled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There must be a mechanism for detecting unauthorized modification to the software or configuration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA software, when first loaded, must be verified as being that supplied from the vendor, with no modifications, and be the version intended for use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must periodically verify the integrity of the software.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must identify any Life Cycle Security Control requirements in the applicable CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This section does not apply to offline CAs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A network guard, firewall, or filtering router must protect network access to CA and KRS equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The network guard, firewall, or filtering router must limit services allowed to and from the CA and KRS equipment to those required to perform CA and KRS functions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Protection of CA and KRS equipment must be provided against known network attacks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All unused network ports and services must be turned off.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any network software present on the CA and KRS equipment must be necessary to the functioning of the CA application.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any boundary control devices used to protect the network on which PKI equipment is hosted must deny all but the necessary services to the PKI equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Repositories, CSSs, KRA/KRO, and remote workstations used to administer the CAs must employ appropriate network security controls.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Networking equipment must turn off unused network ports and services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any network software present must be necessary to the function of the equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The remote workstation used to administer the CA must use a VPN to access the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The VPN must be configured for mutual authentication, encryption and integrity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If mutual authentication is shared secret based, the shared secret must be changed at least annually, must be randomly generated, and must have entropy commensurate with the cryptographic strength of certificates issued by the PKI being administered.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CA must permit remote administration only after successful multi-factor authentication of the Trusted Role at a level of assurance commensurate with that of the CA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Asserted times must be accurate to within three minutes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Electronic or manual procedures may be used to maintain system time.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Clock adjustments are auditable events (see Section 5.4.1).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued by a CA under this policy must conform to the Common Policy X.509 Certificate and Certificate Revocation List (CRL) Profiles \[CCP-PROF\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates must be of type X.509 v3 (populate version field with integer “2”).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Rules for the inclusion, assignment of value, and processing of extensions are defined in \[CCP-PROF\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates must use the following OIDs for signatures:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Signature Algorithm     | Object Identifier                                                                                          |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | sha256WithRSAEncryption | {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) rsadsi(113549) pkcs(1) pkcs-1(1) 11} (1.2.840.113549.1.1.11)                |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | sha384WithRSAEncryption | {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) rsadsi(113549) pkcs(1) pkcs-1(1) 12} (1.2.840.113549.1.1.12)                |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | sha512WithRSAEncryption | {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) rsadsi(113549) pkcs(1) pkcs-1(1) 13} (1.2.840.113549.1.1.13)                |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-RSASSA-PSS           | {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) rsadsi(113549) pkcs(1) pkcs-1(1) 10} (1.2.840.113549.1.1.10)                |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | ecdsa-with-SHA256       | {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) ansi-X9-62(10045) signatures(4) ecdsa-with-SHA2(3) 2} (1.2.840.10045.4.3.2) |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | ecdsa-with-SHA384       | {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) ansi-X9-62(10045) signatures(4) ecdsa-with-SHA2(3) 3} (1.2.840.10045.4.3.3) |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | ecdsa-with-SHA512       | {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) ansi-x962(10045) signatures(4) ecdsa-with-SHA2(3) 4} (1.2.840.10045.4.3.4)  |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The PSS padding scheme OID is independent of the hash algorithm.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The hash algorithm is specified as a parameter (for details, see \[PKCS#1\]).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under this CP must use the SHA-256 hash algorithm when generating RSASSA-PSS signatures.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The following OID must be used to specify the hash in an RSASSA-PSS digital signature:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | SHA-256 | {joint-iso-itu-t(2) country(16) us(840) organization(1) gov(101) csor(3) nistalgorithm(4) hashalgs(2) 1} (2.16.840.1.101.3.4.2.1) |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates must use the following OIDs to identify the algorithm associated with the subject key:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | Public Key Algorithm | Object Identifier                                                                           |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | rsaEncryption        | {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) rsadsi(113549) pkcs(1) pkcs-1(1) 1} (1.2.840.113549.1.1.1)   |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: | id-ecPublicKey       | {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) ansi-X9-62(10045) id-publicKeyType(2) 1} (1.2.840.10045.2.1) |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where the certificate contains an elliptic curve public key, the parameters must be specified as one of the following named curves:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |Curve|Object Identifier|

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: |ansip384r1|{iso(1) identified-organization(3) certicom(132) curve(0) 34 } (1.3.132.0.34)  |

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The subject and issuer fields of certificates issued under this policy must be populated with an X.500 Distinguished Name as specified in Section 3.1.1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Name constraints may be asserted in CA certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under this CP must assert at least one policy OID as specified in Section 1.2 in the certificate policies extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates that express the id-fpki-common-cardAuth, id-fpki-common-pivi-cardAuth, id-fpki-common-piv-contentSigning, or id-fpki-common-pivi-contentSigning policy OID must not express any other policy OIDs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Delegated OCSP

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Responder certificates must assert all policy OIDs for which they are authoritative.

groups.title: Usage of Policy Constraints Extension Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CAs may assert policy constraints in CA certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When this extension appears, at least one of requireExplicitPolicy or inhibitPolicyMapping must be present.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When present, this extension may be marked critical.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For certificates issued to the Federal Bridge CA, inhibitPolicy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mapping skip certs must be set to 2.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For all other CA certificates issued by the Federal Common Policy CA, inhibitPolicy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mapping skip certs must be set to 0.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When requireExplicitPolicy is included, skip certs must be set to 0.

groups.title: Policy Qualifiers Syntax and Semantics Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under this CP may contain a policy qualifier containing a CPS URI.

groups.title: 8.1.8 Processing Semantics for the Critical Certificate Policies Extension
Processing Semantics for the Critical Certificate Policies Extension Controls

controls.title: Processing Semantics for the Critical Certificate Policies Extension

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates issued under this policy must contain a non-critical certificate policies extension.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CAs may assert InhibitAnyPolicy in CA certificates.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When present, this extension may be marked critical.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Skip certs must be set to 0, since certificate policies are required in the Federal PKI.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CRLs issued by a CA under this CP must conform to the CRL profile specified in \[CCP-PROF\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CAs must issue X.509 Version two (2) CRLs.

groups.title: CRL and CRL Entry Extensions Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Detailed CRL profiles addressing the use of each extension are specified in \[CCP-PROF\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CSSs operated under this policy must sign responses using algorithms designated for CRL signing.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All CSSs must accept and return SHA-1 hashes in the CertID and responderID fields.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CSS may accept and return additional hash algorithms within the CertID fields.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CSSs must not return any response containing a hash algorithm in the CertID that differs from the CertID in the request.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CSSs operated under this policy must use OCSP version 1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Critical OCSP extensions must not be used.

groups.title: Compliance Audit and Other Assessments Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy are subject to an annual review by the FPKIPA to ensure their policies and operations remain compliant with this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must have a compliance audit mechanism in place to ensure that the requirements of their CPS are being implemented and enforced.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organization’s PMA must be responsible for ensuring annual audits are conducted for all PKI functions regardless of how or by whom the PKI components are managed and operated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Agencies must ensure they have appropriate authority to operate, in accordance with \[FIPS 201\] and \[NIST SP 800-79\]

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Guidelines for the Accreditation of PIV Card Issuers and Derived PIV Credential Issuers (DPCI).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Agencies must also ensure annual PKI compliance audits are conducted for all PKI operations for which they are responsible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For the Federal Common Policy CA, the FPKIMA must have a compliance audit mechanism in place to ensure that the requirements of this CP are being implemented and enforced by its CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP does not impose a requirement for any particular assessment methodology.

groups.title: Frequency or Circumstances of Assessment Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs and RAs operating under this policy must be subject to an annual compliance audit in accordance with the FPKI Annual Review Requirements document \[AUDIT\].

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA has the right to require aperiodic compliance audits of CAs operating under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA must state the reason for any aperiodic compliance audit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: On an annual basis, for each PCI configuration used (as defined by the FIPS 201 Evaluation Program), one populated, representative PIV credential must be submitted to the FIPS 201 Evaluation Program for testing.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The auditor must demonstrate competence in the field of compliance audits, and must be thoroughly familiar with the CA’s CPS and this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The compliance auditor must perform such compliance audits as a regular ongoing business activity.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition to the previous requirements, the auditor must be a certified information system auditor (CISA) or IT security specialist, and a PKI subject matter specialist who can offer input regarding acceptable risks, mitigation strategies, and industry best practices.

groups.title: Assessor’s Relationship to Assessed Entity Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The compliance auditor either must be a private firm that is independent from the entities (CA and RAs) being audited, or it must be sufficiently organizationally separated from those entities to provide an unbiased, independent evaluation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An example of the latter situation may be an agency inspector general.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: To ensure independence and objectivity, the compliance auditor may not have served the entity in developing or maintaining the entity’s CA facility or Certification Practices Statement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA may determine whether a compliance auditor meets this requirement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each agency is responsible for identifying and engaging a qualified auditor of agency operations implementing aspects of this CP.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The purpose of a compliance audit must be to verify that a CA and its RAs comply with all the requirements of the current versions of this CP and the CA’s CPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All aspects of the CA/RA operation must be subject to compliance audit inspections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Components other than CAs may be audited fully or by using a representative sample.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If the compliance auditor uses statistical sampling, all PKI components, PKI component managers and operators must be considered in the sample.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The samples must vary on an annual basis.

groups.title: 9.4 Actions Taken as a Result of Deficiency
Actions Taken as a Result of Deficiency Controls

controls.title: Actions Taken as a Result of Deficiency

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When the compliance auditor or FIPS 201 Evaluation Program testing finds a discrepancy between the requirements of this CP or the stipulations in the CPS and the design, operation, or maintenance of the PKI Authorities, the following actions must be performed:

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The discrepancy must be documented;

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The responsible party must be notified; and

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: - The party responsible for correcting the discrepancy will propose a remedy, including expected time for completion, to the FPKIPA and appropriate agency.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Depending upon the nature and severity of the discrepancy, and how quickly it can be corrected, the FPKIPA may decide to temporarily halt operation of the CA or RA, to revoke a certificate issued to the CA or RA, or take other actions it deems appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The FPKIPA will develop procedures for making and implementing such determinations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A compliance audit or FIPS 201 Evaluation Program test may be required to confirm the implementation and effectiveness of the remedy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: On an annual basis, CAs operating under this policy must submit an annual review package to the FPKIPA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This package must be prepared by the CA’s PMA, in accordance with the FPKI Annual Review Requirements document.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The package must include an assertion that all PKI components have been audited including any components that may be separately managed and operated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The report must identify the versions of this CP and the CPS used in the assessment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Additionally, where necessary, the results must be communicated as set forth in Section 8.5 above.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each agency must provide an Auditor Letter of Compliance for those PKI components that it operates to its issuing CA or directly to the FPKIPA.

groups.title: Certificate Issuance or Renewal Fees Controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must make this determination.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Section 2 of this policy requires that CA certificates be publicly available.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must not charge additional fees for access to this information.

groups.title: 10.1.2 Revocation or Status Information Access Fees
Revocation or Status Information Access Fees Controls

controls.title: Revocation or Status Information Access Fees

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must not charge additional fees for revoking certificates or access to CRLs and OCSP status information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must make this determination.

parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must make this determination.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: This CP contains no limits on the use of certificates issued by CAs under this policy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Rather, entities, acting as relying parties, must determine what financial limits, if any, they wish to impose for certificates used to consummate a transaction.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must make this determination.

parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must make this determination.

groups.title: 10.2.2 Insurance or Warranty Coverage for End-Entities
Insurance or Warranty Coverage for End-Entities Controls

controls.title: Insurance or Warranty Coverage for End-Entities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CAs operating under this policy must make this determination.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: CA information not requiring protection must be made publicly available.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Public access to organizational information must be determined by the respective organization.
